Rebecca is a farmer who lives in the town of Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur with her family. She is married and has four children.

Rebecca and her husband are both farmers. They both till their land where they grow rice crops. Rebecca works hard to help support her family.

Rebecca requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes to have an abundant harvest. Rebecca also hopes for her family's living conditions to improve.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter was born in 1974; he is married and has two children who are in school. He does tailoring to earn a living for his family. He started the business in 1999, and he has witnessed a lot of growth since he joined Faulu Kenya. He has also been able to save his money through Faulu Kenya. Peter hopes to invest in other businesses in the future. He has requested 20,000 KES to buy buttons, fabric, and thread.

loans.use: To buy buttons, fabric, and thread.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Rosemarie works hard to support her family.

She has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines. Rosemarie is borrowing PHP 19,500 through NWTF to buy spare parts for her motorcycle transport business.

Rosemarie has been sustaining her business activities through her past 18 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for her motorcycle

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea, 52, is living in Baray District, Kompong Thom Province, Cambodia. She lives with Yong, 53, and their three children whom they care for and provide with a good education. Now, one of her children has already married and lives independently. Chea strives to provide the best for her family members; she works hard for them in her fields planted with rice, corn and bananas. She’s been in this line of work for many years on land of her own. 

Taking time from the farming business, she run a business as a fish seller in one market near her community. From this business, she earns approximately $2 per day. To upgrade her family to be more comfortable, Chea would like to raise a cow but lacks capital, so she has already decided to request some funds through HKL, a partner with Kiva.This is her second loan with HKL; therefore, she’s hoping for a small loan to reach her objectives, and she is naturally disposed to repay her loan punctually. She hopes that this loan will make her family meet with happiness and prosperity all the time.

loans.use: to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.es: Faustina, de 35 años, es una mujer trabajadora, vive en una casa alquilada junto a sus 02 queridos hijos, Cintia de 16 y Maylin de 14 años, a quienes desea brindar una mejor calidad de vida. Las chacras que con tanto esfuerzo ha cultivado Faustina, siempre le han brindado los ingresos necesarios para educar a sus hijas, ella cultiva plantas de cacao, café y hojas de coca, una vez cosechados los lleva a vender a distintas empresas acopiadoras de dichos productos. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es sembrar sus tierras y lo hace con mucha paciencia. Lleva 15 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es cuidar sus cultivos de la  plaga de insectos. Para el mejor porvenir de los miembros de su familia espera contar con la misma fuerza e ímpetu de seguir labrando sus tierras y por ello se encomienda a dios todas las mañanas. Este será su segundo crédito con MFP, sabe que el dinero del crédito le será de mucha utilidad en el progreso de su trabajo, por ello agradece una vez mas a los financistas por permitirle trabajar con ellos. Con los 3,000 nuevos soles comprará plantas de café para ampliar su producción.
texts.en:
Faustina is 35, and a hard-working woman. She lives in a rented house with her two dear daughters, Cintia 16, and Maylin 14, to whom she wishes to offer a better quality of life.

The fields that Faustina has cultivated with so much effort have always provided her with the income necessary to raise her daughters. She grows cacao, coffee, and coca leaves. Once harvested, she sells them to the different middlemen who buy these products. 

What she most likes about her work is planting her land, and she does it with a lot of patience.  She has been doing this work for 15 years, and considers that protecting her crops from insect infestations is her most difficult challenge.  To provide a better future for the members of her family, she hopes to have the strength and energy to continue working her land, and for that she entrusts herself to God every morning.  

This will be her second loan with MFP. She knows that the money from the loan will be very useful in advancing her work. For that, she once again thanks the lenders for allowing her to work with them. With the 3,000 nuevos soles, she will buy coffee plants in order to expand her production.

loans.use: To buy coffee plants.

loans.name: Yaye Diakhou

texts.fr: Madame Yaye  est une veuve de 54 ans. Elle vit au  Sénégal. Elle évolue dans le secteur du commerce depuis plus de 25 ans. Elle pratique la vente de petit déjeuner, de pommes de terre et d’oignons  dans le quartier ou elle habite. La raison qui l’a poussé à choisir cette activité est la recherche de revenus qui lui permettent de subvenir à ses besoins  personnels  mais aussi a ceux de ses petits-enfants.  C’est un parent bénéficiaire qui a déjà bénéficié de 21 prêts  antérieurs  au sein de l’un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC ou elle est membre depuis juillet 2000. Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000 prévus pour l’achat des produits qu’elle commercialise.  Elle  veut renforcer son fond de roulement et lutter contre les fluctuations  des prix des produits dues  a l’hivernage.
texts.en:
Mrs. Yaye, age 54, is a widow and lives in Senegal. She's been in the trade business for more than 25 years. She sells breakfasts, potatoes and onions in the neighborhood where she lives. She chose this business in order to earn an income to support herself and her grandchildren.

She's a parent who already benefited from 21 loans from Kiva's partner, U-IMCEC, of which she's been a member since July 2000.

She's seeking a loan of XOF 100'000 in order to buy products for resale. She wants to bolster her working capital and fight against price fluctuations during the rainy season.

loans.use: to buy products for resale (breakfasts, potatoes and onions)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase merchandise such as  lingerie, jackets, sweat shirts, shirts, pants, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy school supplies and uniforms

loans.name: Melba

texts.en:
Melba is 37 years old and married with one child.

Melba works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a 20,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell.

Melba has borrowed and repaid 16 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 11 years and also earns an income from farming sugarcane and from motorcycle transport.

Melba aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Jose Alfredo

texts.es: El señor José  vive en anticrético hace varios años, se dedica al transporte público, manejando el vehículo de su hijo, el crédito lo necesitan para comprar un carro de hamburguesas ya que quiere incursionar en la venta de hamburguesas ya que en la zona existe un complejo de canchas deportivas y es lleno de jóvenes todas las noches y el quiere aprovechar esta oportunidad y poner a la venta hamburguesas, salchipapas, es una persona luchadora, se siente agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: Señor José has lived in Anticrético for several years. He is a taxi driver and drives his son's vehicle. He needs the loan to buy a hamburger cart as he wants to start selling hamburgers. There is a sports complex in the vicinity which is full of young people every night and he wants to take advantage of this opportunity to sell hamburgers and salchipapas (a traditional sausage and chips dish). He is a determined person and is grateful to the institution for the support given.

loans.use: to buy a hamburger cart.

loans.name: Mercidita

texts.en:
Mercidita is 38 years old and married with six children. She is from Tukuran, Zambaonga del Sur in the Philippines.

To make a living, Mercidita runs a general store, selling a variety of food and home products to the local community such as candies, cigarettes, shampoo, soaps and many other things. She has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 3,600 PHP a month.

In 2010 Mercidita joined GDMPC to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.

Mercidita is so happy now, since she has doubled her income through her third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use any additional revenue generated to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.es: Samuel de 57 años de edad casado con Maura de 50 años de edad, fruto de esta relación tienen 3 hijos viven en la comunidad de Monterrico del distrito de Sivia. Samuel, es bueno y bondadoso pero de carácter fuerte para los retos, cuenta que hace un tiempo atrás recayó de salud donde descuido su trabajo, cuando ya recuperado regreso a sus labores vio que las maleza había invadido todo su campo agrícola, que por momentos pensó en dejarlo. Pero mas fue su entusiasmo, laboriosidad y amor a la agricultura que decidió empezar a quitar las malezas, juntamente con su querida esposa e hijos. Una vez que terminó de sacar toda la maleza de su cultivo de café empezó a fertilizarlos ya que el crecimiento de la maleza succionaron los nutrientes del suelo. Pero su salud aún es delicada, por ello ha decidio emprender otro nuevo giro de negocio que es la venta de abarrotes en su propia casa por lo que requiere un nuevo capital. Por tanto será su tercer credito con MFP, por lo que se compromete en cancelar puntualmente el pago de sus cuotas. Con los 1,000 nuevos soles comprará productos de primera necesidad para abastecer su tienda.
texts.en:
Samuel is 57 years old.  He’s married to 50 year old Maura, they have three children, and live in the Monterrico community within the Sivia district.  Samuel is a good, kind man, but with a strong character for meeting challenges.  He says that his health got bad some time ago and he paid less attention to his work.  When he recovered, he started working again and saw that so many weeds had invaded his farmland that at times he wanted to give them up.  But his enthusiasm, a desire to work, and a love for farming were greater and he had to begin removing the weeds, with the help of his loving wife and children.  Once he finished removing all the weeds from his crops, he started fertilizing them because the weeds had taken all the nutrition from the land.

His health is still delicate, so he decided to start another business; selling groceries out of his home.  This requires new capital.  He will use the 1,000 PEN ($375) from this loan to buy primary needs products to stock his store.

loans.use: to stock his store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy bulk groundnuts.

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
At the age of 20, Jenelyn is married and has one infant child. She is married to a jeepney driver. She wanted to add to her husband's income, so she established a small store inside her house.

She is now asking for a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy sardines, instant noodles, soap, and detergent to sell in her retail store. She would like to stock more grocery items in her store so that she can meet all her customers' demands; for example, they might need a sachet of shampoo.  

In the future, she hopes to construct a more convenient store.

loans.use: to buy sardines, instant noodles, soap, and detergent to sell in her retail store.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 30 years old and is married to Alice.  They are blessed with one child.  He has been running a boutique for the past two years with a monthly income of KES 16,000.

He is applying for his first loan of KES 30,000 with KADET Ltd after being introduced by an existing customer.  He will use the loan to buy stocks of new clothes for his business.  With the anticipated profit from the business he will educate his child. 

His hopes and dreams are to expand his business and open a retail shop for his wife, which will help him improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to buy new clothes for his business.

loans.name: Gloria2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe GLORIA2 est composé de trois personnes qui sont issues du même pays. C'est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Akpamè est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Akpamè est âgée de 26 ans et est une célibataire. Akpamè n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Akpamè vit seule et assure seule ses différents besoins. Pour subvenir à ses différents besoins, Akpamè vend depuis trois ans des vêtements, des jus de bissape et de sucettes. Cette activité lui permet de répondre sans grande difficulté à ses besoins. Akpamè s’approvisionne au TOGO. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Akpamè sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe GLORIA2, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le premier prêt a été bien remboursé.
texts.en: GLORIA2 is a group made up of three women from the same country.  In order to increase its activity, the group is requesting financial assistance from ALIDé for a second time.  The group's facilitator, named Akpamè, is raising her hand in the photo.  Akpamè is 26 years old and single.  She has not attended school.  She lives alone and takes care of her own needs.  In order to support herself, she has been selling clothes, bissap tea (made from hibiscus flowers) and popsicles for three years.  This business allows her to provide for herself without any major difficulty.  Akpamè buys her merchandise in Togo.  In order to meet her customers' needs and to increase her turnover and income, Akpamè is requesting a second loan from ALIDé, along with the other two members of GLORIA2.  The groups's first loan was well repaid.

loans.use: To buy clothes, cartons of milk and sugar.

loans.name: Anahi

texts.es:
Anahi es comerciante, se dedica a la venta de celulares económicos de procedencia china los cuales los adquiere en la frontera, comercializándolos en una zona de la ciudad de La Paz donde se puede adquirir todo tipo de electrodomésticos, vive en la casa de sus padres en la ciudad de La Paz.
El crédito lo necesita para incrementar de su capital, adquiriendo nuevos modelos de celular y  de esta manera poder aumentar sus ingresos.

El sueño de Anahi es poder comprar su casa propia brindar a su familia mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Anahí’s a merchant.  She sells inexpensive Chinese-made mobile phones that she gets at the border and sells in a sector of La Paz where all sorts of electronic appliances can be found.  She lives in her parents’ house in the city of La Paz.

The loan she needs is to increase her capital acquiring new mobile phone models thus being able to increase her income.  Anahí’s dream is to be able to buy a house of her own to provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to buy mobile phone supplies.

loans.name: Lahai's Group

texts.en:
Lahai is a member of this group from Iraq. Lahai is 53 years old widow  . Lahai started her sewing business five years ago with an old sewing machine. 
She is requesting this (Qard Hassan ) loan that Izdiharona provide for divorced and widow women to buy sewing machine to help her increase her income.
She aims to open big place for her business and create jobs for other women.
The story of Lahai and her business is just one of the many examples of Izdiharona for economic development clients .
They preferred to blur their face to cultural reason.

loans.use: A portion of Lahai's Group $ 3,000 loan is to buy sewing machine.

loans.name: Jorge Fabricio

texts.es:
Jorge es propietario de un punto express de servicio a domicilio de gas propano, él es soltero, vive junto a su madre y sus tres hijos, tiene que cumplir con la responsabilidad de sacar adelante a sus hijos, el negocio lo tiene hace ya un año, sus clientes son sus vecinos y negocios de venta de comida que están ubicados en la zona, su horario de trabajo es de seis de la mañana a seis de la tarde, se ventaja es la gran experiencia que ha ido adquiriendo, el oficio lo aprendió siendo empleado.
Invertirá el crédito en la compra de cilindros de 25 y 35 libras, así como también en llenarlos de gas licuado, tendrá un mejor equipo para atender las necesidades de sus clientes, espera saber administrar su negocio para progresar, los riesgos son el índice de delincuencia existente en la zona.
Sus proyectos son mejorar su negocio, comprar una motocicleta para repartir gas y ayudar económicamente a su familia.

loans.use: compra de cilindros de 25 y 35 libras, así como también en llenarlos de gas licuado, tendrá un mejor equipo para atender las necesidades de sus clientes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Leah would like to invest in shares on the stock market.

loans.name: Tula De Jesus

texts.en:
My name is Tula, and I sell food. I sell from Monday to Friday to clients who are visiting their families in this area of the capital. I need to supply my business with food so that I can increase my sales.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Tula y me dedico a la venta de comidas a personas que lo pidan, mis ventas las hago de lunes a viernes y mis clientes son personas que visitan a sus familiales en esta zona de la capital. Necesito surtir mi negocio con alimentos para mejorar mis ventas.

loans.use: To buy tortillas, lard, soft drinks, chicken, vegetables, rice, beans, and other food items

loans.name: Natavan

texts.en:
Natavan is 30, a mother of 2 children,  an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fizuli region, settled in Dilagar village.
She is a very active and responsible woman.5 years ago she decided to start this business.Now she needs a loan of $950 to expand the area of her store.

loans.use: To expand the area of her store

loans.name: Eim

texts.en: Mrs. T. Eim was married in 1989 and has 4 children. She has been farming since 1985. She is currently planting and selling different kinds of vegetables and other food crops in the local market and sometimes brings them to sell in the city market. Her husband is a mason contractor in rural communities. With the profits from the family business, all of their children are able to go to school. This is her first loan from MAXIMA, and the loan amount is $300. She will use this loan to purchase fertilizer and pesticide for planting vegetables and food crops. She has the ability to repay the loan to MAXIMA.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Isidoro

texts.en:
Isidoro L. is 38 years old, married to Mrs. Luciana Viveros, and is the father of 3 children, one in secondary school and the other two in elementary school. They all live in his mother-in-law’s house, located in downtown Acahay. In order to open his grocery store in 1990, he was supported by his parents and relatives. He started with a small amount of capital and supplied his small grocery store with basic foods such as: pasta, rice, sugar, mate, flour and others. It has been a great success, since it is located in a well populated neighborhood and these products are daily essentials. In addition to the aforementioned activity, Isidoro works as a middleman selling bricks and other materials in the construction industry. This is a very important supplementary income in order to improve the quality of life for him and for his family. The loan will be used for purchasing groceries, and bulk products to be packed for selling, such as rice, flour, sugar, corn, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Isidoro L. tiene 38 años de edad, casado con la señora Luciana Viveros, tienen 3 hijos, uno de los hijos está en la secundaria, y los otros dos en edad escolar. Todos viven en la casa de su suegra en el centro de la ciudad de Acahay. Para poder empezar a montar la despensa, en el año 1990, con la ayuda de sus familiares, padre y madre, comenzó con un pequeño capital, desde ahí Isidoro empezó a surtir su pequeña despensa con productos de primera necesidad, tales como: fideo, arroz, azúcar, hierba mate, harina, y otros, con gran éxito por la ubicación ya que está en un barrio muy habitado y estos productos son necesarios para la comida diaria. Además de esta actividad, Isidoro trabaja como intermediario en la venta de ladrillos y demás materiales para la industria de la construcción, esta actividad es un suplemento muy importante para poder aumentar su ingreso y aumentar su nivel de vida y la de su familia. El préstamo será utilizado para la compra de mercaderías, productos a granel y envasarlos para su venta tales como arroz, harina, azúcar, maíz, etc.

loans.use: Purchasing rice, flour, sugar, corn, etc.

loans.name: Thi Lap

texts.vi:
Ms Lập is 50 years old. She has 3 children all grown up. Before she used to sell fabric at the market but she had switched to raising poultry. Her husband has experience in raising poultry. They put their effort into raising chickens for meat and eggs. Everyday she sells chicken eggs at the market. She's requesting a loan to buy more chickens. To be able to pay back the loan in small installments suits her fine.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si,.Kiva volunteer.

Cô Lập năm nay 50 tuổi, cô có 3 người con, các con cô đã lớn.Trước kia cô thường đi chợ buôn bán vải, nhưng bây giờ co chuyển sang chăn nuôi.Chồng cô là người có kinh n ghiệm trong chăn nuôi, gia đình cô chủ yếu là nuôi gà thịt và gà đẻ.Hàng ngày cô đi bán trứng. Cô đi vay vốn đợt này để mua gà tăng gia thêm.Hình thức trả góp dần hàng tuần cô rất thích.

loans.use: Having loans for purchasing chicken

loans.name: Sipaea

texts.en: Sipaea is a 67-year-old mother of five children, all of whom have jobs. She works hard at her grocery store, which is located in the village of Vaitele and open 7 days a week, from 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Sipaea has done very well because she offers people lower prices and better quality than they can get elsewhere, and she is attracting a growing number of customers. After expenses, she earns $100 per week in profits, which she saves or uses to repay loans to SPBD. She is looking forward to her new loan, which she will use to expand her grocery store and help her family renovate their home.

loans.use: To restock her grocery store and renovate her home

loans.name: Central A (Ii) Group

texts.en:
Aisha is married with three chidren. She is a diary farmer. She supplies milk to a small restaurant near her home. She wants to buy more fresian cows with the extra profits and also pay school fees for the children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more milk cans and buy a fridge.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Mariam's Tujikwamue. Group

texts.en:
Mariam is a 42 year-old married woman with one child, age 8. She and her husband also take care of three other people, ages 33, 30 and 22. Mariam is a chips seller, a business which she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 4 a.m. to 8 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $10 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan of $900 to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in fish sales, café operations, and shop sales.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is the twenty-nine year old operator of a small auto parts store. David has been selling auto parts of different kinds for over eight years. He will use the loan proceeds to purchase more clutch disks and pressure plates from Japan, Korea and Germany. In Ghana there are no auto parts stores, but there is a high demand for parts as the taxi networks are the main transportation option. His stand operates in an area of Accra called Abossey-Okai that is a conglomeration of hundreds of entrepreneurs who each sell specific auto parts.

David hopes the loan proceeds help him increase his sales volume and profits so that he can buy his own store or rent a store. Currently, he travels with all of his products to his stand everyday. With a permanent space, he could store his products overnight.

David is a member of the lending group Respect. The lending group works as a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: David would like to buy more clutch disks and pressure plates for his auto parts store.

loans.name: New Canada 2009-3 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is 28-year-old Margaret D., who is requesting a loan to expand her bread-selling business. Margaret is married and has four school-going children ranging from age 10 to 15. Each week, she makes approximately 360 Sudanese pounds in profits, and with the extra profits that will result from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children’s school fees.

Margaret is joined in her small group by Pita A., Mary J., and Rejina S.. Pita A. has a business in selling vegetables and wants to buy a car. Mary J. is currently operating a business in selling at the hotel and wants a loan to expand. Rejina S. operates a business selling charcoal and also wants to expand.

loans.use: To expand the business.

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria Auxiliadora N. is a native of San Rafael del Sur in the city of Managua. She runs a business making and selling prepared meals. She is known as an excellent cook since she has worked in the culinary business for years.

She is the mother of one and is responsible for covering the daily costs of her humble home. She currently needs to purchase raw materials to make the delicious meals that she sells from her shop. She is seeking a loan from Ceprodel in order to purchase those ingredients in order to continue offering meals to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Auxiliadora N. es originaria del municipio de San Rafael del Sur en la ciudad de Managua. Allí se dedica al negocio de elaboración y venta de comida preparados por ella misma para ofrecerlos en el negocio. Se caracteriza por ser una excelente cocinera ya que posee varios años de dedicarse a este oficio.

Actualmente es madre de un hijo el cual mantiene y además es responsable de cubrir las necesidades de su humilde hogar. Hoy en día para elaborar los deliciosos platillos ella requiere de la compra de la materia prima para su respectiva elaboración. Es por este motivo que ella busca el apoyo en Ceprodel para obtener el crédito necesario para la compra de estos ingredientes para continuar elaborando los mejores platillos para sus clientes.

loans.use: Purchase of food ingredients

loans.name: Jose Ernesto

texts.es:
I have been working at a school as a prefect for years now. My wife has been working at a factory for many years as well. I am requesting a loan because I need to set up a small general store in my home so that my wife can work in our own business because she has been doing heavy work for a long time. This way, we would increase our income and she could rest. I am requesting a loan of $1,000.00 USD so that we can start our small general store.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Yo trabajo en una escueL. D. prefecto hace ya años, mi esposa trabaja en una maquiladora D. igual manera por muchos años, es por esto que pido un préstamo por que tengo L. necesidad D. poner una miscelánea en mi casa para que mi esposa pueda trabajar en un negocio propio ya que lleva mucho tiempo trabajando y es un poco pesado, D. esta manera tendríamos ingresos mas propios y elL. pudiera descansar. Solicito el préstamo D. $1,000.00 dlls. Y así poder poner L. tienda D. abarrotes.

loans.use: Set up a small general store

loans.name: Haoua

texts.fr:
Mrs. Haoua Dembelé is 50 and lives with her 7 children (3 sons and 4 daughters) and her husband in a monogamous household in Sogomougou district in Koutiala Prefecture (the third economic region of the Republic of Mali). For financial reasons she was not able to attend school and began early on to undertake money-generating activities, particularly the sale of snacks and dyeing cloth. In the end, she opted to specialize in dyeing cloth, a business her mother had always been in (she learned the skill from her mother).

After 20 years of doing this work in her home, she has an excellent reputation in the town of Koutiala. Her products sell easily and the demand for them is steadily growing.

In order to meet this demand, Mrs. Haoua Dembélé decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now requesting her first individual loan.

She buys her “bazin” (a sort of damask; cloth much prized in Mali and in West Africa) in the big open-air market of Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali) and sometimes at the market in Koutiala from specialized wholesalers. She sells her products at home, in the big outdoor market of the town of Koutiala (displayed under a shed roof), or door-to-door, for credit or cash. She sends part of her production to San (the neighboring town near Koutiala) where her sister sells dyed “bazin”. Her clientele is essentially made up of women and a few men. The period before festivals is when she produces and sells the most.

With this loan, she intends to buy 1 length of “rich bazin” in white, 5 lengths of less rich “bazin”, 5 kg of dyes of different shades, and 5 kg of potash.

She expects to make a profit of 80,000 FCFA monthly which she will use to make the payments on the loan and contribute to family expenses, investing any remainder back into her business. Mrs. Haoua Dembélé intends to diversify her activities by opening a shop where she can sell dyed “bazin” and a sales point for dyes and potash for other Koutiala women engaged in dyeing cloth.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

Madame Haoua Dembelé à 50 ans, et vit avec ses 7 enfants ( 3 garçons et 4 filles) et son mari dans une famille monogame au quartier Sogomougou de la préfecture de Koutiala.(troisième région économique de la république du Mali). Pour des raisons sociales elle n’a pas fréquenté l’ècole et s’est très vite interessée aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment la vente des friandises et la teinture. Finalement elle opta pour une spécialisation en teinture de tissus, activité que sa mère mène depuis toujours (et auprès de laquelle elle appris ce métier).

Après 20 ans d’exercice de cette activité à son domicile, elle jouit d’ une réputation sans pareille dans la ville de Koutiala. Sa production est ecoulée rapidement et la demande est de plus en plus importante.

Afin de faire face à cette demande Madame Haoua Dembélé décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et est à son premier prêt indivudiel.

Elle s’approvisionne en Bazin (tissus très prisé au Mali et en Afrique de l’ouest) au grand marché de Bamako( la capitale de république du Mali) et quelques fois au marché de Koutiala auprès des commerçants grossistes du domaine. Elle vend sa production à domicile, au grand marché de la ville de Koutiala sous un hangar sur une étale, en ambulant à crédit ou au comptant. Elle envoie une partie de sa production à San (ville voisine de Koutiala) où sa soeur fait le commerce de bazins teints. Sa clientèle est constituée essentiellement de femmes et de quelques hommes. Les périodes de fêtes constituent les périodes de grande production et de vente.

Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 1 pièce de bazin riche de couleur blanche, 5 pièces de bazin moins riche, 5 kg de teinture de différentes couleurs et 5 kg de potasse.

Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice de 80.000FCFA par mois qu’elle utilisera pour payer les intérêts du prêt subvenir aux dépenses de famille et investir le reste dans l’activité. Madame Haoua Dembelé compte diversifier ses activités en ouvrant une boutique de vente de bazins teintés et un point de vente des teintures et de potasse à l’intention des teinturières de Koutiala.

loans.use:
Purchase of lengths of white "bazin" damask (cloth that is highly prized in West Africa)

Achat des pièces de bazin blancs (Tissus très prisé en afrique de l’ouest

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a talented 41-year-old woman who owns her own business producing "faux bijoux," or costume jewelery and accessories for women. Fatima lives in a small village close to Nabatieh in Southern Lebanon and she makes and sells these beautiful and popular products herself.

Women throughout the village know Fatima for her work, and much of her business comes from friends and relatives who pass on the word about her stylish jewelery products to others. She is member of a solidarity lending group called "Al Araada," which in Arabic means "The Will."

Indeed Fatima has a very strong will, and she is determined to succeed in her business. In order to purchase new materials which will help her diversify the jewelery she makes, Fatima has requested a loan of US$ 300. Fatima is confident that this capital will enable her to expand her business, and she will repay her loan over a period of four months. This is the first loan Fatima has requested from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Purchase new supplies of metals and gems to make costume jewelery

loans.name: Maletina

texts.en: Maletina I., 58, is married with 10 children. She has many years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to villagers and general public 7 days per week. She has had 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD). SPBD loans are Maletina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for renovating her house, to purchase timber, sacks of cement, and iron roofing. Her pancake business is very famous around her area due to her secret recipes.

loans.use: To purchase a frying pan, sack of sugar, sack of flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en: Mrs. Yeng S., 31 years old, and her husband, Mr. Kong Dam, live on an island located fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Married in 1995, they had two children, one passed away, while another studies in the local school.  Mrs.Yeng has been a silk weaver for ten years. She learned the skill from her neighbors when she was sixteen years old. She sells finished products to a trader in the village, who then sells her products in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a fisherman who fishes from the lake near their house and sells them in the village. Mrs.Yeng is requesting a loan of $100 to purchase thread for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase thread for weaving business.

loans.name: Ascencion Felipe

texts.es:
El Señor Ascensión Felipe V. Dávila tiene la edad de 48 años su estado civil es soltero, este Señor tiene 5 hijos de los cuales 3 dependen de el su hijo mayor de18 años cursa el 5 año de secundaria su otro hijo de 16 años cursa el 4 año de secundaria y un niño de 11 años que cursa el 5 grado de primaria, sus deseos son de darle mejoras a su vivienda por lo que no ha podido realizarlas debido a que los costos de  materiales para construcción están muy altos, en sus propósitos esta el brindarle a su hijos ayuda en los estudios para que estos puedan tener un futuro orientado en los estudios.


La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la venta y elaboración de sorbetes de los siguientes sabores: fresa, piña, chocolate, frambuesa, limón y naranja el tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio es de 11 años, Don Ascensión inicia este negocio por cuenta propia su esposa era la que sabia como se realizaba la elaboración por que ambos trabajaban donde un amigo Don Ascensión se encarga de la venta del sorbete mas tarde decide el mismo instalar su propio negocio su esposa le enseño la elaboración y consiguió y así como obtiene el negocio, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo que es para la reparación de sus refrigeradoras ya que son útiles para la elaboración y también es para la compra de saborisantes por lo que necesita ambas cosas para satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Ascensión Felipe V. Dávila is 48 years old. He is single and has 5 children, 3 of whom are dependents. His oldest son, who is 18 years old, is in his fifth year of secondary school. His 16-year-old son is in his fourth year of secondary school and his 11-year-old son is in the fifth grade of primary school. His dream is to renovate his home. He has not been able to fulfill his wish because the prices of construction materials are very high. One of his goals is to help his sons in their education so they can have a future based upon their studies. His primary economic activity is selling and creating ice creams of the following flavors: strawberry, pineapple, chocolate, raspberry, lemon and orange. He has owned his business for 11 years. Don Ascensión began this business with his wife. She was the one who knew how to make the ice cream and both of them worked at a friend's place. Don Ascensión was in charge of sales. Later on, he decided to start his own business and his wife showed him how to make the ice cream. This is how he started his business. The money from the loan will be used to repair his refrigerators because they are useful in the ice cream-making process. He also wants to buy additional flavorings. He needs both the refrigerators and the flavorings to satisfy customer demand.

Translated from Spanish by Priya Bapat, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Sarei's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarei C. is a leader of a group with four members who all live in Me Meang village in KampO. Chhnang province. She is 41 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others attend the local school. She and her husband, Mr. Sum Yath, are farmers who own a small piece of land where they cultivate rice. They face a problem because their field is infertile and thus yields poor crops. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Sarei C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make her land more productive. 
One member of this group has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These loans allow borrowers to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has an overall delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to make her land more productive.

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en: Alaa is a 34-year-old man who is married and has four young children. He and his family live in Sabra, Beirut. He inherited a car body shop from his father, after working in the shop for 20 years. Today, he wants to borrow $1200 so he can add a car accessories section to further expand his business.

loans.use: Buy car accessories

loans.name: Lorenda

texts.en:
Mrs. Lorenda M. hails from Sibalom, Antique, Philippines and is blessed with ten children. At the moment, she has encountered challenges in the schooling of her 2 high school students. Being a mother of 10 is a serious matter, that’s why any problem encountered at her age of 55 is just a part of ordinary life.

"Nanay" (Mama) Lorenda is engaged in buying and selling bamboo products and charcoal. She started with only 10 sacks of charcoal. She had lots of customers such as restaurant owners, neighbors, students and employees. As of now, she and her relative share one stall, that’s why she dreams of having her own shop to display all her products since the customers are satisfied seeing her bamboo products. She is also accepting orders for bamboo as another source of income.

She perseveres to have a name in this kind of business and send her children to school so that they will have a good future someday. She also would like to establish her own shop to display all her bamboo products there. For her, ASHI is a great help for her business, providing capital and insurance for death, and business training that will mould ASHI members' lives.

loans.use: Buying and selling bamboo products and charcoal

loans.name: Mrs. Savy Put Village Bank Group

texts.en: Nineteen people who live in the Svay Chuor Village in the Kandal Province form the village bank loan, and all the members will use the loan which they've obtained for different purposes. Mrs. Savy P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She sells vegetables in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Noav Chhroeng, helps with her business. Since their business is doing well, they want to expand it by purchasing more vegetables to resell in order to earn more income to support their family. Mrs. Savy P. is a 34-year-old mother of four children, one of whom is a vegetable seller while two others are enrolled in the local school, and the remaining is too young to work or study. Mrs. Srey T. is not present, but her husband, instead, is shown in the picture with the village bank members.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to resell

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites M. is enthusiastic and determined to give full support to her husband, a tricycle driver. They are blessed with 3 children: 2 are already in school and the other one is a baby.

Both Marites and her husband try hard to improve their lives. She helps him find ways to earn a living for the family. Currently, she buys and sells corn. Sometimes she finances fertilizer for the farmers; those loans are payable within 15 days. Today, Marites needs capital amounting to PHP 11,000 to purchase corn and fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and corn

loans.name: Loi

texts.en:
Lợi C. is a 30-year-old female and is living in the town of Hưng yên. She is married and has two school-aged children.

To make a living, Lợi owns & operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from manufacturing and selling clothing products to local businesses and community members. She has now been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000,000 VND a month (approximately 220 U.S. dollars) from these activities.

In 2007, Lợi joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products.

Lợi is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. Lợi plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina G. is rice farmer. She is 28 years old and has 1 child. She is married to a farmer, Archie G.. They want to provide, for their child, a bright future so they are working very hard to supplement their income. Divina is aiming to send her child to college, a dream that she failed to achieve herself.

She is asking a loan of PHP 10,000 (USD 225) from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and seeds. She needs financial assistance in her farm especially since the costs have increased. The loan will really help to increase her income even more.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that aims to help small business to grow. It provides not just loans but also training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase fertilzers and seeds for farming rice.

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
Lily has run a typical village store and a food vending business for almost 13 years. She is earning a weekly net income of PHP 1,500. She would like to avail a loan amounting to PHP 7,000 as additional working capital for her food vending business. She is choosing to maintain her food vending instead of her general store because she believes that she will be able to generate higher income from food vending. 

She is married to Freddie Agdinaoay, a farm laborer in their village. They were blessed with 3 children; Nico is 14 years old, Allan is13 years old, and April Marie is 8 years old. The three are currently studying in high school and elementary school. The family lives together with her parents in law at the moment since they don’t have their own house to live in. Lily tries her best to save money both for the education of their children and for a house of their own someday.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Đỗ Thị

texts.en:
K. Đỗ Thị (539081702) is a 49-year-old female living in the town of Ý Yên. She is married and has two adult children. To make a living, K. owns and operates an agricultural business raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale. K. has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 4,100,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, K. joined Kiva partner, TYM Fund, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. K. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. K. is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND, which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. The loan will be her second from TYM Fund. K. plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Juana Quintina

texts.es:
La señora Juana pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nueva Generación 2000”  que esta ubicado en el distrito D. Ilave, Provincia D. El Collao, Departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 62 años D. edad, está casada y es madre D. 01 hijo ya independiente, ella no tiene estudios,  vive en la Calle Ramón Castilla.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 9 años,  su primer préstamo fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que invirtió en su negocio D. venta confección D. polleras (faldas típicas D. la Región).

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo D. S/. 2000.00 Nuevos soles, para poder comprar tela D. diferentes colores y así pueda elaborar más polleras las mismas que pondrá en venta.

Su mayor deseo es seguir trabajando para solventar sus gastos.

A ella le gustan las reuniones y las charlas recibidas por el personal D. Manuela Ramos.
texts.en:
Ms. Juana H. is a member of the “Nueva Generación 2000” Microfinance Institute, located in the Ilave district of the El Collao province, department of Puno. She is a 62-year-old married mother with 1 independent child. She received no schooling and lives on Ramón Castilla Street.

She has been working with the Manuela Ramos movement for 9 years. She invested her first 300.00 PEN loan in her pollera (regional skirt) business.

At this time, she needs a 2,000.00 PEN loan so that she can purchase different-colored fabric and make more skirts to sell.

Her greatest wish is to continue working so that she can cover her personal expenses.

She likes the meetings and chats that the Manuela Ramos personnel gives.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric to make traditional skirts

loans.name: Tersesa Luz

texts.es: La Señora Teresa Luz C. tiene 65 años. Es una madre una madre soltera. Tiene 2 hijos a su cargo. Por lo que su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 13 años que se dedica a este negocio. La ubicación de su humilde negocio es en su vivienda. La mayoría de sus compras las realiza en el mercado. Ella tiene sus clientes a quienes  compra las golosinas entre otras cosas, Teresa es una mujer muy agradable y por medio de este negocio ha podido sobrevivir y sufragar los gastos. El destino del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de golosinas, granos básicos y productos diarios. El deseo de Teresa es brindar una estabilidad económica a su familia.
texts.en:
Teresa Luz C. is 65 years old. She is a single mother. She has 2 children under her care. She runs a small general store. She has dedicated herself to this business for over 13 years. Her humble business is located in her home. She does most of her shopping at the market. She has clients who buy candies amongst other things. Teresa is a very pleasant woman and through this business he has been able to survive and cover her expenses. The loan will be used as work capital to purchase candies, basic grains, and other every day products. Teresa’s dream is to offer her family financial stability.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital (to purchase candies, basic grains, and other every day products).

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
MRS. EMILY Y. is 36 years old, married with 2 school-age children, and lives in Prk. Malipayon, Brgy. Canjusa, in the coastal municipality of Pulupandan, Negros Occidental.

For the past 7 years since she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, Emily admits that she has learned a lot in how she should manage her business so that it could grow and continue to help support the growing needs of her family of 4.

Emily has a food stall in the local market where she sells Ginamos, a local delicacy, and this earns her on the average PHP 12,000.00 per month.

Because Ginamos has to be aged, and production is dependent on the availability of the krill, Emily needs additional working capital so that she could maintain the ideal volume of Ginamos on stock. She needs to borrow PHP 20,000.00 as additional capital to sustain her expanding business.

Emily is working hard to provide for her her children. She is using the income she earns in this business venture to pay for the tuition fees of her 2 children. 

What is Ginamos?
Ginamos is a generic Hiligaynon (the local dialect in Western Visayas) term for anything that is salted and aged to ferment - in Tagalog it is known as Bagoong. Ginamos can also refer to fermented salted fish, mussels, oysters, etc. but in general, the term Ginamos refers to mashed salted fermented krill - all the others must be qualified - e.g. Ginamos na isda (fermented salted fish) or Ginamos na Tahong (fermented salted mussels).

Ginamos is prepared by mashing sea salt and krill together until the salt is well mixed into the finely ground krill, then it is kept in containers to age until ready. Ginamos in Negros Island is usually moist but firm and sold by the block or smaller bricks. Vendors usually pre-cut the blocks into different sizes to offer the buyers a selection. People usually buy Ginamos either as a flavor enhancer to dishes like Pinakbet (a vegetable stew) or as a dish by itself. When cooked as a dish, it is usually mixed with vinegar and sauteed with lots of garlic and sometimes with fried pork rind, and is served with rice as a meal or with green mangoes as an appetizer.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL WORKING CAPITAL

loans.name: Gulshan

texts.en:
Gulshan lives in the town of Istaravshan with her husband and three children. She has had a retail business for about 8 years and is in the process of expanding it. Gulshan sells a variety of clothing for women in local market. By offering a range of clothing items, she provides a convenient stop for her customers who often will buy more than just one item from her. Gulshan has requested a loan to increase her working capital and help sustain her business. Purchasing inventory from wholesalers has required a substantial investment from Gulshan, which is why she decided to obtain a loan. This loan will give her added flexibility and will help cover some of her growing expenses while she develops a larger business. Additional profits generated by her business will provide her with stable income and the ability to support her family financially. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of clothing for selling

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en:
Youssef is 30 years old, married, and has three children. He lives in Bint Jbeil, Southern Lebanon and owns a grocery store. In his store, Youssef sells all kinds of food products as well as computer and electronic games.

Youssef is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy new products for his store. It is his second year as a microcredit client.

Youssef has faced financial problems in the past. He hopes to expand his store and increase the types of products he sells in the future. Youssef is known for his people skills as well as his expertise in running businesses.

loans.use: To buy inventory for a grocery store.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace T., 21 years old, is a rice farmer from Veruela Agusan del Sur. She is helping her parents manage their small rice field, which the hope will give enough income to buy food, clothing and to provide for other basic needs.

She heard about CEVI in their town. She likes the 2% interest rate because, for her, it is very low and easy to repay. She would like to apply for aloan of PHP 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm and to buy the farm necessities. By doing so, she believes she will be able to obtain an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm financing.

loans.name: Omotayo

texts.en: Omotayo is 30 years old, married and has two children. She makes a living selling bags of charcoal to both wholesale and retail customers. Omotayo has applied for a loan to buy more bags of  charcoal to sell. She extends sincere thanks to all Kiva lenders for making it possible for her to do this.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Ndejje B Nakayiza Mayi Group

texts.en: N. Mayi, a 30-year-old single woman, has been operating a beauty salon for three years so far. She is blessed with two children, who are in school, and she is looking after her mother in her home. She is using this loan to purchase salon items such as a drier, chemicals and hair extensions, etc. She praises our loan, since it is stress free. She is so encouraged and hardworking! Her dream is to educate her children and to attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase salon items such as a drier, chemicals, hair extensions, etc.

loans.name: Ser-Od

texts.en: Ser-Od B. is 42 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a house in the Zavkhan Province of Western Mongolia. His wife works as a kindergarten teacher. His daughter and son, ages 13 and 11 respectively, attend a local secondary school. Ser-Od works as a carpenter. He has owned his carpentry business for almost 17 years and, over this long time, he has earned the loyalty of his customers because of the quality of his work and service. Ser-Od currently runs his business out of a rented space and would like to expand his product line in order to enlarge his customer base. He is requesting a 300,000 tugrug (approx. $211 USD) loan to purchase more timber for his growing business. XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team. To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more timber for his growing business

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana J. is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables in the market and is requesting a loan to buy other items like fish, groundnut paste, and rice to sell. Diana is 30 years old and is married to a is a fisherman. She has 3 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy items like fish, groundnut paste, and rice to sell

loans.name: Geneliza

texts.en: Geneliza C. is from the village of Dabubu Grande. Geneliza is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Geneliza raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Geneliza earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities. In 2009, Geneliza joined ASKI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Geneliza is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Geneliza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Gantulga

texts.en:
Gantulga S. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian  housing tent called "ger." His son and daughter, ages 14 and 9, both attend a local secondary school. 

Gantulga operates a transportation service in his town. He transports small loads such as luggage or supplies for individuals and local businesses throughout the area. Gantulga started his business in 2008 with capital of 5,000,000 tugrugs after previously operating a window making-business. Since starting his transportation service, he has improved and expanded his business greatly. Today, his working capital exceeds 10,000,000 tugrugs. 

Gantulga is an energetic person and has many goals for himself and for his business. He says, "With my future earnings, I plan to buy two more trucks for my business." 

He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to make improvements to his business.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mr. Sokhorn R., 38, and his wife, Mrs. Nimol Peang, 30, live along national road number one about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1991 and have three children: one son and two daughters. One of the children attends school and the other two are still young.  

Sokhorn has been a farmer for 18 years. He grows corn and tomatoes. His wife has been selling vegetable for two years. She buys some of vegetables from other farmers in her village and some her husband grew and transports to sell in Bek Chan market about 40 kilometers from her house. 

Sokhorn is applying for his first loan of $600 to purchase a cart for his wife to carry vegetables that are for sale.

loans.use: To purchase a cart for his wife to carry vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Albertine Dohoué

texts.fr: H. Albertine Dohoué est née le 20 Juin 1983 à Cotonou, la capitale économique du Bénin. Albertine Dohoué est mariée à DJOI ASSOGBA Symphorien, un soudeur. Le couple a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Agbato, un quartier de Cotonou. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Albertine Dohoué n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Albertine Dohoué vend des condiments de sauce (tomates fraîches, piments, épices, etc.) et des légumes à son domicile. C’est à Adja dans le Mono (au Bénin) que Albertine Dohoué s’approvisionne. Albertine Dohoué est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits auprès de l’institution, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Albertine Dohoué ambitionne renforcer son capital et agrandir davantage son étalage, pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Cependant, Albertine Dohoué ne dispose pas d’assez de fonds pour y arriver. C’est pourquoi Albertine Dohoué sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Albertine Dohoué H. was born June 20, 1983 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Symphorien DJOI ASSOGBA, a welder. The couple have four children, who are all in school. The family lives together in Agbato, a neighbourhood in Cotonou. The couple share household expenses. Albertine Dohoué has not attended school. To cope with her various expenses, Albertine Dohoué sells sauce condiments (fresh tomatoes, hot peppers, spices, etc.) and vegetables from her home. She gets her supplies from Adja in the Mono region of Benin. Albertine Dohoué is a former beneficiary of ALIDé, having already been granted four loans, all of which were fully reimbursed. Her ambition is to bolster her working capital and expand her stall offerings to better satisfy her customers. However, she lacks the funds to do so. This is why Albertine Dohoué is requesting a fifth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy baskets of fresh tomatoes and hot peppers

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en:
Felomina R. is a married woman who supports her family by selling fish. She lives in Brgy 1 Siaton, Negros Oriental, with her husband and their seven children, who are 5 to 33 years old.  Three of their children are currently studying and four are working to help their parents.

Felomina has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since May of 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000.00.

Felomina is now borrowing Php 19,500 so that she can have revolving capital for her fish vending business. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Felomina aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them "Dungganon" - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Nkobazambogo Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
K. Daudi (shown inset top left as well as in the main photograph) is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a determined and hardworking married man with three children aged four, six and nine years old. He also takes care of his parents.
Daudi has had a grocery business in Ngogwe for two years, from which he makes 120,000 UGX as weekly profit. Before he had this business, he was just a farmer. With the help of a loan, Daudi has learned to take his produce to the market. He also buys from other farmers when his stock is not sufficient. He ensures that his produce is of good quality and mostly deals in fruit and vegetables. He hopes to expand his customer base depending on what he has for sale.
For the future, Daudi has a plan of buying a plot of land in the trading center in the hope that he can make it a commercial success once he has the funds to do so. He is requesting a loan to buy more produce for resale.

loans.use: To buy more produce for his grocery business

loans.name: Eduardo Agustín

texts.es:
El crédito lo utilizó para la compra de discos, CD, ya que el titular se dedica a la venta ambulante de dichos productos hace mas de un año , siendo la zona que vende  la ciudad de Luque y el interior del país, para dicho trabajo se moviliza en una motocicleta, ya que posee una  buena clientela formada a la fecha.
Cabe resaltar que la familia de señor Eduardo es muy trabajadora y todos se ayudan con el fin de salir adelante dignamente.
texts.en:
This loan will be used to buy CDs, since this person is a street vendor who has sold these products for more than a year. He sells these items in a neighborhood of the city of Luque and in the interior of the country. For this work he travels by motorcycle. He currently has a good customer base. It should be noted that the family of Eduardo is very hardworking and they all help him with the aim of getting ahead in a respectable manner.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy music CDs

loans.name: Sandra Maribel's Group

texts.es: Sandra, Andrea y Doña Raymunda se dedican a actividades diferentes, Sandra tiene una tienda en su casa en la cual vende articulos de consumo diario, Andrea se dedica a la compra y venta de periodicos en su casa y Doña Raymunda tiene una tortilleria y se dedica también a la crianza de gallinas, cerdos, etc. esto le ayuda y también tiene 2 hijos en Estados Unidos los cuales le envian ayuda, Doña Raymunda solicita el crédito para poder comprar mas concentrado para sus animales y maíz, ya que en esta época es mucho mas barato
texts.en:
Sandra, Andrea y Raymunda make a living in different activities. Sandra runs a store out of her home selling grocery items, Andrea buys and sells periodicals out of her home and Raymunda has a tortilla shop and also raises cattle, pigs and other animals. Raymunda also has two children in the United States who send back money. She is requesting the loan to purchase more feed and corn for her animals since those items are very cheap at this time.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grains and other items

loans.name: Arnel

texts.en:
Arnel D., age 30, is from the village of Poblacion Sapang Dalaga. He is married and has three small children. To make a living, Arnel is engaged in the retail sector, particularly in the selling of household items. Through this activity, he is able to earn a monthly net income amounting to 5,000.00. 

In 2005, Arnel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. He wanted to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Arnel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for his business. Arnel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new stocks for his store. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Arnel from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase household items to offer for sale in his store

loans.name: Souleymane

texts.fr: Monsieur Souleymane S. est un éboueur qui exerce ce métier depuis 1978 après avoir quitte la Compagnie Sucrière Sénégalaise. Il a démarré  grâce a la proposition  de la mairie. Monsieur S. habite a Yoff Mbenguene et a 56 ans d’existence. Il est marie et père de 6 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 10 et 33 ans. Son revenu mensuel étant insuffisant pour nourrir une telle famille il emprunte 50 000 frs pour aider son fils tailleur a acquérir une machine a coudre dans l’espoir que ce dernier avec revenus pourra apporter un soutien a la famille.
texts.en:
Mr Souleymane S. has worked as a dustman since 1978 when he quit working at the Senegalese Sugar Company. He began here thanks to an offer from the town authorities. Mr S. lives in Yoff Mbenguene and is a 56 year- old married father of 6 children aged between 10 and 33. Since his monthly income is not enough to feed his family, he is seeking to borrow 50 000 FRS to help his tailor son to buy a sewing machine in the hope that this will bring in revenue to help the family.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es: La Sra. Mercedes se dedica a la fabricación D. sombreros para cholita estos sombreros es parte D. la vestimenta tradicional D. la Chola Paceña, tiene mucho tiempo en esta actividad, su esposo le ayuda a elaborarlos y ella los venD. en las ferias D. la ciudad D. El Alto D. La Paz, tiene tambien algunos pedidos dentro D. la ciudad por la zona D. Pampahasi que es donD. ella vive, es muy conocida por la zona, sus hijos ya son independientes, pero no se descuidan D. sus padres; doña Mercedes es una cliente muy puntual  y muy antigua D. la institución. El crédito que solicita ahora es para la compra D. material, en especial para el fuste que la base para realizar el sombrero, comprará el nacional ya que hay D. dos clases el nacional y el brasilero; ella comprará el nacional ya que tiene pedidos D. este material. Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Mercedes makes hats for “cholitas” (women of Aymaran or Quechan decent). These hats are part of the traditional clothing for the Chola Paceña (women of Aymaran or Quechan decent). She has been doing this for a long time. Her husband helps her make them, and she sells them at the fairs in the cities of El Alto and La Paz. She also has some orders within the city in the Pampahasi area where she lives. She is well known in the area. Her children are independent, but they do not neglect their parents. Mercedes is a very punctual client, and she has worked with the institution for a very long time. The loan she is now requesting is to buy materiel. She will especially buy the “fuste”, which is the base for making the hat. She will buy the national. There are two types, the national and the Brazilian. She will buy the national because she has orders for this material. She is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust shown in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials for making hats

loans.name: Ten

texts.en: N., 57, lives in the rural area of Kompong Tom Province, where she owns a small business, the main activity of which is to weave baskets for sale. She married years ago and has four children, two of whom are now married and the remaining two are going to school. Her husband is the main provider who works producing furniture to earn a living. N. is looking for a loan for her husband to increase the capital of his furniture-making trade.

loans.use: To increase business capital.

loans.name: Sarita Group

texts.es:
El grupo Sarita lo integran tres mujeres emprendedoras, esforzadas y decididas una de ellas es Rosa del Carmen G., coordinadora del grupo. Ella desde hace cinco años comercializa cosméticos y joyería de manera ambúlate. La meta de G. es poder tener su propio local donde pueda vender más segura y con una mejor instalación.

Sus compañeras de grupo son Anielka Jahoska M. L. de 23 años tiene una pequeña pulpería y María José C. Guzmán vende ropa y cosméticos  desde hace seis años y sueña con tener su propio local.
texts.en:
The Sarita group is comprised of three enterprising, hard-working, and determined women. One of them is Carmen G., the coordinator of the group. She has been selling cosmetics and jewelry as a traveling merchant for five years. G.’s goal is to be able to have her own place where she could sell more safely and have better facilities. Anielka Jahoska Montaon L., a colleague in the group, is 23 years old. She has a small mini market. María José C. Guzmán, her other colleague, has been selling clothes and cosmetics for six years. She dreams of having her own place.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cosmetics and jewelry

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase sewing materials such as thread, small- and big-sized scissors, and so on

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr: Née en Janvier 1963 à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique, H. Véronique vit depuis trente sept ans au quartier Dogoudo à Allada. Véronique est mariée à GBOGLI François, un mécanicien, et est mère de cinq enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Parmi les enfants, trois seulement sont à la charge du couple. Véronique vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. N’ayant pas été à l’école, Véronique mène comme activité depuis une vingtaine d’année, la vente de l’huile de palme à Allada. Véronique s’approvisionne dans les villages d’Allada. C’est la troisième fois que Véronique sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue d’augmenter davantage le stock de ses produits et d’élargir son champ d’activité.
texts.en:
Born in January 1963 in Allada in Benin’s Atlantique Department, Véronique H. has lived for 37 years in the Dogoudo neighborhood of Allada. She is married to François Gbogli, a mechanic, and has five children, some of whom are in school. Only three of the children are currently in the couple’s care. Véronique lives with her husband and children. The couple shares the family’s expenses. Never having been to school, Véronique has been selling palm oil for 20 years in Allada. She buys her supplies in the villages of Allada. This is the third time that Véronique is requesting a loan through ALIDé, with the goal of increasing her inventory and widening the scope of her business.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 13 cans of palm oil.

loans.name: Go Before Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, Northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Go Before” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in order to invest in their businesses. 

Isatu C. is the leader of this group. Isatu is fifty-seven years old and married with three children – two in primary school and one in secondary school. Isatu sells dishes and has been doing this business for many years now. With the help of this loan, Isatu will invest in her business by buying different kinds of dishes and in large quantity to add to her business inventory. 

(Also included in the photo is loan officer Zainab B., pictured in the right, handing over the loan.)

loans.use: Buy different kinds of dishes, in large quantity

loans.name: Mercedes Eugenia

texts.es:
Mercedes de 64 años, vive en el Guasmo de Guayaquil, es viuda con tres hijos, tiene una pequeña tienda en la parte delantera de su casa.
