Hace 5 años murió su esposo ella se quedo sola con sus tres hijos, tuvo que invertir  sus ahorros en vivieres y readecuar la parte delantera de su casa para tener su pequeña tienda y así mantener a sus hijos. Desde ese tiempo hasta ahora ella ha trabajado desde las 08h00am hasta las 21h00pm todos los días, en ocasiones se enferma y recae por su edad pero sigue trabajando para asegurar su vejez. 

Ella quiere comprar con el préstamo arroz, aceite y papelería para surtir su tienda. En el futuro quiere readecuar su casa para dársela a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mercedes is a 64-year-old widow who lives in Guasmo de Guayaquil and has three children. She runs a small general store in the front part of her house.

When her husband passed away 5 years ago, she was left to raise her three children on her own, so she had to invest her savings in purchasing provisions and remodeling the front part of her house so that she could set up her general store and support her children. Since then, she has been working from 8am until 9pm every day. On some occasions, she falls ill due to her age, but she continues to work in order to ensure a peaceful old age.

She would like to purchase rice, cooking oil, and stationery with this loan so that she can restock her shop. In the future, she would like to remodel her house so that she can give it to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, cooking oil and stationery

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: Julia, de 40 años, vive en su casa que es propia en compañía de sus 2 hijos y de su suegra, habitan en un barrio populoso ubicado al norte de la ciudad. Hace más de 2 años, se dedica en la venta de productos de belleza de una reconocida marca, recuerda como se animó a empezar en este negocio por recomendación de una amiga. Y cuando recién comenzaba a colocar sus productos, todo era muy difícil pero con el tiempo adquirió buenas clientes que ahora le compran con frecuencia y le pagan a tiempo. Le gusta mucho su trabajo porque le permite obtener buenas ganancias sin descuidar su hogar, además ha logrado sacar adelante a sus hijos con mucho empeño y dedicación. Pero  lo que le desagrada es caminar mucho para captar  nuevas clientes, pues siempre esta en busca del crecimiento. Esta trabajadora mujer tiene planeado para más adelante instalar un pequeño bazar  en su casa y de esta manera continuar adelante. Es el tercer crédito que tiene con MFP, y promete cumplir con sus cuotas puntualmente ya que quiere seguir progresando, además no quiere decepcionar a las personas que hicieron posible el dinero que le permitirá continuar trabajando. Julia tiene planeado invertir el crédito solicitado en la compra de mayor cantidad de productos de belleza y perfumes, pues tiene varios pedidos por cumplir y espera tener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Julia is 40 years old and lives in her own home with her two children and her mother-in-law. They all reside in a populous neighborhood located north of the city. For more than two years, Julia has been selling beauty products of a known brand. She remembers starting her business based on a recommendation of a friend. When she first started building up her inventory of products, everything was very difficult, but in time she eventually acquired good customers who now buy on a frequent basis and pay on time. Julia enjoys her work because it allows her to earn a good income without neglecting her household. In addition, her children have been able to get ahead because of her effort and dedication. The part she dislikes is walking great distances in order to attract new customers, but she is willing to do it so that she can keep growing. This hardworking woman has plans to get further ahead by opening a small bazaar in her home so that she can continue forward.

This is her third loan with MFP. Julia promises to complete her payments on time so that she can continue progressing. In addition, she does not want to disappoint everyone who made this loan possible so that she could continue working. Julia plans to invest the loan she requested in the purchase of more beauty products and perfumes since she has several orders to fulfill. She hopes to have a better income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products & perfumes to fulfill her orders

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María, de 46 años, es una madre de familia jovial, es separada y viven en su casa propia, junto a sus dos hijas. Hace más de 9 años, se dedica a la venta de artefactos y artesanías  en general. Es así que cada fin de mes viaja a provincias, llevando variedad de artefactos para el hogar y de regreso  compra cerámicas de arcillas. En un inicio sus clientes eran sus familiares y algunos amigos, pero con el tiempo logró captar clientela. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo, es el viaje que hace a provincias, ya que se distrae mucho y a la vez  se genera sus  propios ingresos económicos. Lleva más de 9 años realizando esta actividad y lo que espera en lo sucesivo es recorrer todo el país, para que así pueda realizar obras de labor social, que la ayuden a favor de los más necesitados de su distrito. Este es su quinceavo crédito con MFP, y sabe que tiene que pagar puntualmente sus cuotas  y esta dispuesta hacerlo. Es la líder de su grupo y como tal es muy responsable. Con el crédito que solicita, incrementará de cerámicas y demás adornos, para atender los pedidos que tiene pendiente.
texts.en:
Maria is 46 years old and she is a very happy mom. She is separated and she lives in her own home together with her two daughters. For more than 9 years she has sold merchandise and general crafts. Every month she travels to the provinces from where she collects household items and ceramics. In the beginning her customers were her family and some friends. But with time she started to gain new clientele. What she most enjoys about her job is having to travel to the provinces. It serves as a distraction and at the same time she is able to secure her own source of income. She has had this business for more than 9 years and what she plans for the future is to travel throughout the entire country, to do some socially conscious work and gain some support for the most in need in the district where she lives. This is her fifteenth loan through MFP (Kiva Field Partner) and she knows she must make her payments on time and she is committed to doing so. She is the leader of a group and as such she is very responsible. With the loan requested she will purchase more ceramics and other decorations and to fill some outstanding orders.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ceramics and decorations to meet client demand

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria A. is from the village of Sta. Rosa. She is 60 years old. Maria is widowed and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Maria owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Maria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Maria is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Maria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Tajihan's Group

texts.en:
Tajihan C. is the leader of the group. She is 57, married. Her husband is a pensioner. Since 1993, the family has had good cotton harvests. Now with the profits from farming,Tajihan would like to cultivate onions as well as cotton. The profits will be used  to arrange their daughter’s and son’s weddings. Tajihan hopes to get a loan in order to purchase onion seeds and fertilizers. She is planning to buy cattle for breeding.

Adalat M., 50, is divorced. She has 2 sons. Adalat together with her son is engaged in farming. A the present time they cultivate water-melon and cotton. They hope to get a loan in order to obtain onion seeds for cultivating. 

Gulzat K., 37, is a widow. She is the treasurer of the group. In 2006 the family had bought a cow for 12000 soms. Since then Gulzat has been engaged in cattle breeding. The loan purpose is to purchase 4 sheep for breeding. 

Saadat S., 26, is married. Her husband earns money by working at the District Electric Power Station. The couple has 2 children. Both of them are of preschool age. The family make their living by farming; they cultivate onion and cucumbers to sell. Saadat needs to get a loan in order to rent a land for vegetable growing. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase onion seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Buuveibaatar

texts.en:
Buuveibaatar A. is a 23 year old young man who lives with his father and siblings in Tosontsengel province, Mongolia. They live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Buuveibaatar is the oldest son in the family and is responsible for providing for his family. He is a jeweler while his brother operates a shoe repair shop in their town. 

He has a lot of skill as a craftsman and designs and produces a variety of jewelry and accessories. He started his business with the help of his father in 2006 and has gained significant experience. Since then, he has worked hard to grow his crafts business, and he currently rents a workplace with his brother. His other sibling is a university student but has stopped attending the university because Buuveibaatar could not afford his sibling's tuition fee. Buuveibaatar plans to work hard and expand his business so that he can collect money to pay his sibling's tuition fee next year. 

He says, " I have many dreams such as expanding my business, having my own work place, and buying a new car. Some of those dreams are in the process of coming true in the real lif.e"  He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase casts and more white silver for his jewelry products making business.

loans.use: To purchase casts and more white silver.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn D. is from the village of Lower Salug Dako Mahayag ZDS. She is 33 years old.

Analyn is an individual member of PMPC. To make a living, Analyn owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from her piggery. Analyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Analyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analyn is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Analyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional capital to buy piglets.

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora A. is from the village of Olango. She is 53 years old. Aurora is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Aurora plants, harvests, and sells rice. Aurora has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Aurora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. Aurora is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Aurora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, such as manure

loans.name: Frederic

texts.en:
Frederic is 45 years old. He is married and has 6 children aged between 7 and 20.  Frederic has 10 years in his business selling different goods in his general store. He employs two people and his business is open from 6am until 8pm.  

Frederic has requested a loan from Kiva via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business. With this loan, Frederic believes he will obtain more profit in goods distribution, which he will reinvest in his business. He hopes for a better future.

loans.use: To purchase more products and items to sell

loans.name: Carlos Armando

texts.es:
Carlos Armando V. M. tiene 20 años, es soltero y vive con sus padres en el cantón de Babahoyo en la provincia de Los Ríos. 

Carlos Armando es miembro de la ventanilla rural Unidos Somos Más. Esta nueva ventanilla hace parte de la comunidad Matilde Esther en la provincia de Guayas. Esta comunidad esta ubicada a 2 horas de la oficina de Chillanes en la provincia de Bolívar. El grupo cuenta con 23 socios y se dedican a diferentes actividades como agricultura, cría de ganados y pequeños restaurantes y comedores.  

Carlos Armando solicita este crédito para comenzar un negocio propio. Este crédito le ayudara incrementar sus ingresos y tener una mejor vida.

Su sueño es incrementar su negocio y tener mejor ingresos para poder ayudar en el hogar de sus padres. Aparte de la baja situación económica no enfrente desafíos en este momento. 

Su hobby es el ciclismo.
texts.en: Carlos Armando V. M. is 20, single, and lives with his parents in the Babahoyo canton in the Los Rios province. Carlos Armando is a member of the Unidos Somos Mas ["United We Are More"] rural lending bank. This new bank is part of the Matilde Esther community in the Guayas province. This community is located 2 hours from the Chillanes office in the Bolivar province. The group has 23 members who have various businesses such as agriculture, the raising of livestock, and small restaurants and cafeterias. Carlos Armando is requesting this loan to start his own business. This loan will help him to increase his income and have a better life. His dream is to grow his business and have a better income in order to be able to help out in his parents' home. Apart from the low economic situation, he does not have any challenges at the moment. His hobby is cycling.

loans.use: to start his own business

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina P. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 29 years old and married. Gina owns and operates a farming business, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Gina works hard to provide for her family.

Gina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Sophon

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophon V. is 37 years old.  Her husband, Mr. Sophea Son, is 38 years old.  They live on an island in the Mekong River, approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1991 and have one son and one daughter. 

Sophon runs a business renting her van to garment factories and individuals. Her husband builds houses.  Sophyn is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to expand her business by purchasing one more van.

loans.use: To add to her own money to purchase a van

loans.name: Segundo Pedro

texts.es:
Segundo tiene 66 años de edad. Vive con su esposa y su hijo en su propia casa en la parte rural del caserío Puente San Francisco en el distrito de Tambogrande, una zona agrícola que se encuentra situada en la provincia de Piura, en la región del mismo nombre, a más de cuatro horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Desde hace 10 años, se dedica a la agricultura, Segundo tiene cultivo de mango y limón. Cuenta con un pequeño terreno cerca de su domicilio. Vende sus productos a una clientela establecida en el mercado local. Aprendió esta actividad de su padre, es decir conoce a la perfección este rubro. 

Desea usar su crédito para comprar fertilizantes para el cultivo del limón. Espera mejorar su producción  para poder ofrecer sus productos en el mercado a un buen precio. Por ello, ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1,500 nuevos soles. Segundo es muy trabajador y encargado a su familia. Agradece el apoyo que los prestamistas de Kiva depositan en él y aprecia la oportunidad de seguir trabajando para mejor la vida de su familia poco a poco.
texts.en:
Segundo is 66 years old.  He lives with his wife and son in his own home, in the rural part of the small village of Puente San Francisco, in Tambogrande district, an agricultural area located in Piura province, in the region of the same name, more than four hours from the city of Chiclayo which is the capital of Lambayeque region.

Segundo has been farming for 10 years.  He grows mangoes and lemons.  He has a small plot of land near his home.  He sells his products to  established customers in the local market.  He learned the trade from his father which is to say that he knows this line of work to perfection.

Segundo would like to use his loan to buy fertilizers for growing his lemons.  He hopes to improve his production so that he can sell his products in the market for a good price.  For this reason, he is requesting a loan for 1,500 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.  Segundo is very hard working and responsible for his family.  He is grateful for the support offered to him by Kiva lenders and he appreciates the opportunity it gives him to continue working so that he can gradually improve his family's life.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for growing lemons

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophy K. (in the photo with her young son) is 28 years old and her husband, Mr. Vanna Seng, is 39 years old. They live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby MeK. River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2001 and have three sons. Two of them are in school and another one is still too young.  

Sophy is a flower farmer. She also buys some flowers from fellow villagers and transports them to sell in a Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a motorcycle repairman. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase additional motorbike spare parts for her husband to respond to his customer’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase motorbike spare parts for her husband’s motorcycle-repairing business

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George S. lives with his family in Martkopi, Kartli Region. He is 30 years old and lives in his house with his wife, parents and daughter. 

George’s wife and mother are housewives and his father works in security. The total average monthly income of the family is GEL 1200, 83% of which comes from George's small business. The family has two milk cows. George sells milk to the grocery shops in Tbilisi, capital city of the country. In addition to his own cows’ production, he collects dairy products from other villagers as well and sells them in Tbilisi. For transportation of the dairy products he uses his own car. 

With the requested loan amount he plans to renovate his car. As a result of the renovation, the expenses on the car fuel will decrease significantly and will cause a 10% increase in the family’s profit. 

With the accumulated increased profit, George plans to purchase additional an milk cow for further expansion of the family's small farm.

loans.use: to renovate a car used for transportation of dairy products.

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn is 25 years old and is a married woman with a 4-year-old child. Her husband works as a tricycle driver and a farmer.

Arlyn is in the hog-raising business. She has a small backyard piggery that she hopes to grow. She fattens the pigs and sells them to the market. Arlyn also helps her husband at the farm. They also own a small banana farm.

Arlyn's loan will be used to purchase seed and fertilizer. She hopes for her businesses to grow.

loans.use: to purchase seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Dominga's Group

texts.en:
Dominga B. is from the village of Catabban. She is 45 years old. Dominga is the leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Dominga B.'s Group.

Dominga is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Dominga owns and operates a furniture-making business. Dominga has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Dominga joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Dominga has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. 

Dominga is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be the 11th loan taken out by Dominga from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Abunzubumwe Rsz Group

texts.fr: Theogene Sibomana est agriculteur de riz, chef du groupe Abunzubumwe, et client d’ACB depuis 2011.  Il est marie, et il a 10 enfants entre 7 ans et 22 ans, et une personne en charge.  Quatre de ses enfants vont a l’ecole.  Il est ne au Rwanda, et il a fini 4 ans d’ecole primaire.  Ce credit est son premier cycle avec ACB, et il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter des fertilisants et payer la main d’oeuvre pour son activite d’agriculture de riz.  Il voudrait devenir un agriculteur moderne dans le secteur de Rusizi, et bien eduquer ses enfants.
texts.en:
Theogene Sibomana is a rice farmer and the leader of the group Abunzubumwe. He has been a client of ACB since 2011. He is married and has ten children, aged 7 to 22, plus he has another person in his care. Four of his children attend school. Theogene was born in Rwanda. He has completed four years of primary schooling. 

This loan cycle is his first one with ACB. He is going to use his loan to buy fertilizer and to pay for labor for his rice-growing business. He would like to become a modern farmer in the Rusizi district and to educate his children well.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and to pay for labor

loans.name: Edjeha Group

texts.fr: EDJEHA est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres habitent le même quartier. La présidente du groupe, Amélie Véronique (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est née le 05 Janvier 1971 à Cotonou Capitale économique du Bénin. Amélie Véronique est mère d’un enfant, et a un autre enfant à charge en dehors de son enfant. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Amélie Véronique  vit depuis sa naissance à Cocotomey dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi. C’est une divorcée, qui vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule les différents besoins. Amélie Véronique  n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Pour se prendre en charge et assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Amélie Véronique mène comme activité depuis cinq ans, la vente de divers produits (yaourt, savon, sucre, lait, maïs, haricot, riz  etc.). Amélie Véronique  achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et les vend à son domicile. C’est la première fois que Amélie Véronique sollicite un crédit auprès de  ALIDé, crédit qui permettra certainement à Amélie Véronique et à son groupe d’accroître leur stock de produits et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle.
texts.en:
EDJEHA is a group of three persons whose members live in the same district. The group's president, Amélie Véronique (with her hand raised in the photo) was born on January 5, 1971 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is the mother of one child, and she has another child in her care besides her own. Both children are in school. She has lived since birth in Cocotomey, in the commune of Abomey Calavi. She is divorced and living alone with her children, and she ensures their various needs are met by herself. 

Amélie Véronique did not attend primary school. To support herself and her children, she has had a business for five years selling a variety of goods (yoghurt, soap, sugar, milk, corn, beans, rice, etc.) She buys her goods at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and sells them at her house. 

This is the first time she has requested a loan from ALIDé. The loan will enable her and her group to increase their stock of merchandise and to respond better the requirements of their customers.

loans.use: to buy a sack of corn, a sack of rice, and three boxes of soap

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is from Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (grand children). 

Margaret has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for 9 years and she works 6 days out of every week. Margaret sells her products from home, by means of wholesale. 

Margaret has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through selling piped water. The main business challenges for Margaret include seasonality and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot of land on which to build rental houses and to own a delivery van.   

Margaret lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es: Gloria es socia del Banco Comunal Fortaleza, tiene 33 años y solicita un préstamo para su negocio de venta de golosinas que vende en su tienda y por teléfono. Ella no está casada y es madre y padre para sus cuatro hijos de 16, 13, 10 y 3 años de edad. Gloria uso el primer préstamo que recibió de FINCA Perú para aumentar su mercadería. Va invertir el crédito que recibirá ahora para empezar la venta de ropa interior en su tienda. La venta de golosinas es un negocio de familia, y ella decidió abrir su propia tienda para poder ayudar a sus hijos económicamente, ya que como madre soltera necesitaría una base fuerte de dinero.
texts.en: Gloria is a member of the communal bank "Fortaleza."  She is 33 years old and is requesting a loan for her business; she sells candy from her home and over the phone.  She is not married and serves as both mother and father for her 4 children aged 16, 13, 10 and 3.  Gloria used the first loan that she received from FINCA Peru to increase her merchandise.  She is going to invest the loan that she will receive next to start selling undergarments from her store.  The candy business is a family business, and she decided to open her own store so that she could help her children financially, since as a single mother she needs a reliable source of income.

loans.use: to buy undergarments

loans.name: Maria Elizabeth

texts.es:
María, es empleada de un comercial que vende productos de primera necesidad, vive con su esposo y dos hijos de 14 y 15 años de edad, ella ha trabajado dos años en la comercial, con un horario de 7:00am a 7:00pm, todos los días de la semana.
Actualmente necesita un préstamo para comprar uniformes, zapatos y otros productos educativos para sus hijos, este préstamo le ayudara a solventar esta situación con sus hijos, y que les permita continuar en el estudio.
Su objetivo es trabajar eficientemente para contar con este empleo por vario tiempo, que le ayude a generar los ingresos para que sus hijos terminen sus estudios y poder pagar las cuotas de este préstamo.
texts.en:
María works as an employee in a store that sells basic household products.  She lives with her husband and her two children aged 14 and 15.  María has worked in this store for two years.  She works from 7.00am to 7.00pm, every day of the week.

María currently needs a loan to buy uniforms, shoes and educational materials for her children.  This loan will help her to cover her children's expenses and allow them to continue in school.

María's goal is to work efficiently so that she keeps this job for a long time, so that it helps her to make the income she needs to enable her children to finish school and also meet her loan repayments.

loans.use: to buy uniforms, shoes and educational materials for her children

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en: Jacqueline, a hardworking 46-year-old single-mother of two, has been supplying wholesale food products since 2008. She also receives extra income from a pension plan that she is registered in.  Jacqueline is requesting a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase more food products to sell such as spices and tea leaves. She is grateful to Faulu Kenya for teaching her how to save her money, and within the next five years hopes to have several more business outlets.

loans.use: to buy food products such as spices and tea leaves to sell.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is 44 years old and married with five children. The oldest child is 20 years old and the youngest is four.

Merlinda is a farmer working in the town of Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She has been growing rice for 16 years. According to Merlinda, she can earn as much as 15,000 PHP per month from farming.

Merlinda is requesting a loan to purchase rice seeds, herbicides and fertilizers. She hopes to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: to purchase rice seeds, herbicides and fertilizers

loans.name: Maria Margarita

texts.es: La señora Maria Margarita, ella tiene 53 años, tiene 3hijos que ya son mayores de edad, ella tiene su negocio que es la venta de comida. Está ubicada en su vivienda, trabaja todos los días desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 10 de la noche pues la mayoría de sus clientes llegan a comprar los diferentes platillos que ofrece, lleva más de 20 años en su negocio y nos cuenta que le va muy bien. Este crédito es para comprar arroz, plátano verde, queso, papas, repollos, bolsas, huevos, aceite y otros ingredientes y productos necesarios para la preparación de los alimentos. Su deseo es seguir adelante en su negocio y que los clientes sigan llegando todos los días.
texts.en: Mrs. Maria Margarita is 53 years old, has 3 children who are independent, and sells food for a living. Her business is located in her own home. She works everyday from 8 in the morning to 10 at night since the majority of of her clients come to buy the variety of plates she sells. She has been working in this business for more than 20 years and she tells us business is going very well. She will use this loan to buy rice, green plantains, cheese, potatoes, cabbage, eggs, oil, and other ingredients and products needed to make meals. Her wish is to continue with her business and for her clients to continue coming everyday.

loans.use: buy rice, green plantains, cheese, potatoes, cabbage, bags, eggs, oil, and other ingredients

loans.name: Razel

texts.en:
This is Razel, who is 45. She is a resident of Payatas, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Loloy, a driver, and is a mother to her only child. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Razel operates a doormat business. Her products are small rugs and larger doormats. She makes door mats out of excess textile cloth she buys from the factory. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. She is also into peanut-butter making. She directly sells her products to her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 25,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric and thread. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Razel hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials needed in her business, like fabric and thread.

loans.name: Anwer's Group

texts.en:
Anwer is a very hardworking lady who operates a business selling artificial jewelry, which enables her to pay the utility bills and manage other household expenses. She started this business after the sudden death of her husband few years ago. She has given birth to three sons. Two of her sons work while the third one is looking for work these days. 

Anwer has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her artificial jewelry business. With the loan, she will buy jewelry of different designs in a larger quantity, which will help her offer better variety to her customers and increase her profits. Eid (a Muslim occasion) is about to come and Anwer is confident that with the loan investment, she can increase her sales and earn good profits. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Anwer.

loans.use: To buy artificial jewelry to sell

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. Merlita has a pigpen. She sells matured & grown pigs. She also butchers the pigs and sells pork per kilogram. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy animal feeds for the pigs.
Merlita has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Merlita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy animal feeds for the pigs

loans.name: Bintijuma

texts.en:
Bintijuma is a single woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a family house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the last four years, she has operated a beauty salon business, her potential customers being neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Bintijuma dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With this 10,000 Kenya shillings (KES) loan, she plans to purchase cosmetics for her beauty salon business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Elvia

texts.es:
La señorita Elvia desea iniciar un negocio de elaboración y venta de comida Mexicana en su propia casa y tener las entrega en diferentes partes de la ciudad. 
Solicita el préstamo para invertir en comprar de los productos y mercancía que es (platos especiales para la entrega, cubiertos de plástico y comprar suficiente a alimentos para la preparación de los platillos que serian chiles rellenos, tamales, enchiladas, guisados) por el momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para invertir en el negocio. 
Planea pagar el crédito con el sueldo que recibe de su trabajo en una compañía de trasportes cono auxiliar administrativo. 
Desea empezar este nuevo negocio y así ayudar a una amiga con darle trabajo y las dos salir adelante y ayudarse en la economía familiar.
texts.en: Elvia wants to start a business making and selling Mexican food at home for delivery to various parts of the city.  She’s asking for the loan to buy the ingredients and merchandise (special dishes for delivery, plastic cutlery and enough food to prepare the dishes which will be chiles rellenos, tamales, enchiladas and stews).  At the moment, she does not have the necessary money to invest in the business.  She plans to repay the loan with the salary she earns working as an Administrative Assistant in a transportation firm.  She wants to start this new business to help a girlfriend employing her so that both of them can get ahead and help each other with their family economies.

loans.use: to start a business selling Mexican food.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase construction materials to extend her kitchen.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 35 years old and married with 2 children. With 2 children in school, she works very hard to provide for them.

Betty runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 27,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell in her sari sari (variety) store. She has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, shampoo, sardines, spices, etc. 

In the future Betty would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy items to sell.

loans.name: Tania Judith

texts.es:
La señora Tania,  es casada  tiene dos hermosas hijas, viven en la  provincia de Mizque del departamento de Cochabamba.
Tania se dedica a trabajar en la magisterio de profesora conjuntamente con su esposo ellos por motivos de trabajo vinieron desde muy lejos. Ahora ellos están iniciando su trabajo en un lugar muy lejano de su lugar de origen, como están iniciando no les alcanza el salario que tienen.    
Tania  es muy querida y respetada en el pueblo de Mizque, por lo que se dedicada a su  trabajo y sus dos  pequeñas hijas, ella está solicitando el crédito para   comprarse un horno industrial para ayudarse en los ingresos económicos que tiene y así  aumentar sus ingresos y mejorar su condición de vida que llevan al realizar trabajos de panadería en lo que también tiene experiencia.  El crédito ayudara mucho en el duro trabajo que realiza.
texts.en:
Tania is married and has two beautiful daughters.  They live together in Mizque province, in Cochabamba department.  

Tania works in the teaching profession together with her husband.  For work reasons, they both came here from very far away.  Now they are starting work in a place which is a very long way from their home town.  As they are just starting out, their salaries are not enough.

Tania is very well liked and respected in the small town of Mizque because of her commitment to her work and her two young daughters.  She is requesting this loan to buy an industrial oven to help her increase her income and improve her living conditions, by carrying out bakery work which is an area in which she also has experience.  This loan will help her a lot in the hard work that she carries out.

loans.use: to buy an industrial oven for carrying out bakery work

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Vanna (pictured with her loom) and her husband, Vuthy, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have four children:  two sons and two daughters. Three of them are in school and the other one is still too young. 

Vanna is a weaver, while her husband is a fisherman and does construction work. 

She hopes to continue her weaving business because it’s a traditional profession, so she is asking for another loan of $400 to buy weaving materials.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
Kelly sigue participando en el banco comunal “Mujeres Emprendedoras” de la Unidad de Micro finanzas de la Asociación  Arariwa de la ciudad del Cusco. Kelly sigue dedicándose a la venta de cosméticos como por ejemplo perfumes, aretes, collares, pinta labios y otras cosas más. 

Kelly con el anterior crédito le fue muy bien y pudo obtener buenos beneficios y por ese motivo desea otro préstamo pues le ayuda mucho. 

Kelly requiere el préstamo para comprar más mercadería como por ejemplo perfumes. 
 
Kelly se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Kelly continues to participate in the “Mujeres Emprendedoras” communal bank of “Unidad de Micro finanzas” of the Arariwa Association in Cusco.  She continues selling cosmetics such as perfumes, earrings, necklaces, lipsticks, and other things.

The previous loan went well for her and she was able to get good benefits from it.  She would like another loan because it will be very helpful.  She needs this loan to buy more merchandise, such as perfume.

Kelly is very grateful for the opportunity given her through this medium and is committed to making her payments on schedule.

loans.use: to buy inventory.

loans.name: Zvikomborero Group

texts.en: This is 42-year-old Joyce from  Machipisa, Harare, a widow with four children, one still at school. Joyce runs a business tailoring baby wear. The business has been in operation for two years. She says the main challenge faced is getting top quality fabrics due to lack of funds. Joyce has requested a loan of $400 to buy top of the range quality fabric. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve her business level and make payment of school fees. In the future Joyce plans to have a big factory and employing a minimum of 10 employees.

loans.use: to buy good quality fabric.

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson, 29, is married to Karen. They are blessed with one five-year-old child. Johnson runs a retail shop that has been in operation for four years.

This is his first loan term with KADET. He will use the funds to buy sugar, rice, cooking oil, and soap for resale. 

Johnson hopes to open a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: to buy flour, rice, soap, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Cyrus

texts.en:
Cyrus is 62 years old, married to Grace and they are blessed with two children. He has been in the farming business for the past 15 years with a monthly income of 10,000 KES which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his first loan with KADET after being introduced by a KADET staff member. Cyrus will use the loan to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm. With the anticipated profit from the business, he will educate his children. 

His hopes and dreams are to keep bees which will increase his income and improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Fernando Jose

texts.es: Fernando es una emprendedor exitoso que tiene experiencia en brindar el servicio de carpintería él es cliente de Fundación León 2000, el crédito anterior lo utilizo para comprar capital trabajo aumentando sus clientes ya que le realizaban pedido. Fernando es muy visitado por sus clientes por la calidad de servicio que brinda. Actualmente está solicitando crédito para comprar herramienta de trabajo, Madera, clavos entre otras cosas
texts.en:
Fernando is a successful entrepreneur who has experience in offering a carpentry service. He is a client of Fundación León 2000. He used his previous loan to buy work capital which increased his client base as he works on demand. Fernando is very solicited by his clients due to the quality of the service he offers. 

This time he is requesting the loan to buy work tools, wood and nails, among other items.

loans.use: to buy work tools, wood, nails, among other items.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Samson is 41 years old and married with two children. He sells bananas to earn a living. He has been in the business for 18 years and describes his business environment as competitive because many people do the same business. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to grow his business and hopes to expand his business in the future. He has applied for 20,000 Kenya Shillings to buy bananas to sell.

loans.use: To buy bananas to sell

loans.name: Olga Lucía

texts.es: Olga de 46 años es una microempresaria del municipio de Nemocón que se dedica a la venta de productos ferreteros y depósito de materiales para la construcción, ella inicio su negocio hace 16 años con el apoyo de su cónyuge y  tras su separación, continuó llevando las riendas de su negocio y su hogar. Ella es madre de tres hijas de 26, 20 y 17 años y su principal anhelo es terminar de costearles sus estudios para que sean unas profesionales competentes.  Todos los días de la semana apertura su negocio a las 7 a.m. y cierra a las 7 p.m. ella es muy comprometida y dedicada para lograr excelentes resultados.  Olga realizó una solicitud de crédito, un credikiva, oportunidad para vincularse a la vida financiera a través de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y surtir con galones de pinturas su negocio para vender en la temporada decembrina, una época en que sus clientes desean realizar algunas remodelaciones en el hogar y aprovechan para pintar su casa. Olga desea continuar trabajando en su ferretería como lo ha hecho con mucha responsabilidad y compromiso y ofrecer bienestar a sus hijas.

loans.use: surtir con galones de pinturas su negocio para vender en la temporada decembrina

loans.name: Béatrice

texts.en:
Béatrice G. was born in Tsévié in 1977. She is a baker and sells bread by the main intersection in town. She is the mother of two children. Her husband repairs tires and makes very little money for covering household expenses, now that business is very slow. So, Béatrice shares in covering all their expenses. Lacking the money to start an independent business, she works for a third party who exploits her. However, with her 8th grade education, she does well. A very dynamic and honest woman, Mrs. G. demonstrates a certain business mastery and plans to set up her own business to augment her income. She is also requesting a loan of $1,200 to construct a traditional kind of oven and to acquire the materials necessary to get her bakery set up. And so she will be able to earn enough money to help improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Madame G. Béatrice est née à Tsévié en 1977. Elle est boulangère et vend du pain au carrefour de la ville. Elle est mère de deux (02) enfants. Son mari, un vulcanisateur qui dispose de peu de moyens pour subvenir à tous les besoins du foyer en ces moments précis où les affaires marchent très peu. Ainsi, Béatrice partage dans les charges du foyer avec son mari. N’ayant pas de moyens pour s’installer à son propre compte, elle travaille pour une tierce personne qui l’exploite. Avec son niveau de la classe de 4ème, elle arrive à bien gérer les affaires. Très dynamique et honnête, Madame G. Béatrice fait preuve de la maîtrise de ses activités et prévoit s’installer en son propre compte pour augmenter ses revenus et améliorer ses revenus. Aussi, sollicite-t-elle un crédit de $1200 pour construire un four traditionnel et acquérir tout le matériel nécessaire pour son installation. Ainsi, elle pourra avoir les moyens suffisants pour contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille.

loans.use: To build a traditional oven and to acquire bakery equipment.

loans.name: Vasili

texts.en: Vasili B. worked at the local community co-operative farm until Moldova regained its independence and collective farming disappeared. Since then he has been working on his private farm and land. Vasili is a widower at 74 years old (his wife passed away about ten years ago) and his one daughter moved to the regional center, located 45 km away, when she got married. Vasili is a very proud man and enjoys working to earn his living. He is eager to purchase seeds and materials to grow different crops this year. He has 2 cows, 4 pigs and 12 sheep, which he keeps on about 2 hectares of land. He would like to take out a loan in order to start planting his land with grains and vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase seeds.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock items for his general shop

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi is married and lives in Zaporozhye in south central Ukraine. He used to work in a factory. However, after the times of perestroika and the collapse of the Soviet Union, he resigned and started working as a market vendor. Unfortunately, he was unable to make enough at that time to meet his family’s basic needs so he decided to try working in construction. After working there for some time his health began to deteriorate and he was forced to quit. In the meantime, his wife had begun working at the market trying to make ends meet and so Yuryi decided to join her. He was able to get enough money together to purchase a supply of batteries, bulbs, dishware, and other small items to start a small vending kiosk. Today, Yuryi has a successful business selling household items in one of the local markets. 

Previous loans have secured the sustainability of Yuryi’s business by promoting his sales and allowing him to purchase a new vending stall. Currently, he has two vending facilities which operate efficiently bringing him stable income. Yuryi is requesting a loan of $500 to increase his available working capital. We believe Yuryi’s integrity and responsibility will help him further progress towards his goals and objectives.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Idrissa

texts.en: Idrissa is thirty two years old and married with four children. He runs a clothing and plastic sandals shop in the town of Magburaka in Sierra Leone.  He has been in business for more than five years. He would like to increase his stock for the Christmas season sales.  He said it will be season to make a good profit, therefore one should have good stock of clothes, with attractive fashions to attract more customers.  For these reasons he is requesting a loan of $350.

loans.use: Increase his stock of clothing in anticipation of high demand during the Christmas season.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Born in 1950, Elizabeth is married and is a mother of four children all above the age of 15 years.

As an ambitious woman, her dream of seeing all her children educated was almost shattered because she and her husband were unable to pay their school fees. This caused her to start the business of selling fruit and groundnuts so she could raise some money to support her husband.

With a loan of $100 (40,000 FCFA), she plans to continue in the same line of business, which she believes will succeed given the fact that she sells near a secondary school where many students buy. She plans to repay the loan in 12 -15 months, with the first installment on the day the loan is received.

loans.use: To purchase fruit, bread and groundnuts

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Thoeun S., age 23, sells rice and food, earning around $7/day in revenue. Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver, making about $4/day of income. They have one child who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a plot of land to grow crops to feed her family.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to grow crops.

loans.name: Kabowa 1(B) Group

texts.en:
Margret sells charcoal in the market. She wants to use the extra business profits to construct a house (storage) for the charcoal, and also to pay school fees for the children. Sylvia is a tailor and wants to use the loan to buy more thread and a new sewing machine. Goret wants to use the loan to pay rent for her salon. Aisha wants to purchase more firewood with the aquired loan, and Regina intends to purchase more hides and skins.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To enlarge the business by stocking more charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in planting of rice crop.

loans.name: Slamas

texts.en:
Mrs. Slamas H. is widow with one son. Her husband died when her son was young. Her son helps her to sell fish. Their house is along the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Slamas has been selling fish for eighteen years. She buys fish from fishermen in the Mekong River for resale at Prek Anchanh Market, about seven kilometers from her village. She and her son carry the fish from the fishing lot to the market in their old motorbike.

Mrs. Slamas is requesting a loan for the third time in the amount of US$600 to replace an old motorbike with a new motorbike to use to sell fish.

loans.use: To buy new motorbike for their fish business

loans.name: Oumou Khairy

texts.fr:
Oumou Khairy D., age 51, takes care of seven children. She is the treasurer of the TP Takku Liguèye village bank in Kolda where she plays a very important role. Oumou sells palm oil, honey, and peanut butter. She would like to include the sale of chicken meat. With the profits of the previous cycle, she bought chicks and constructed a place to shelter them. She is requesting this 18th loan to continue her business and to buy feed for the chicks. This loan will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Oumou Khairy D., 51 ans, 07 enfants en charge est la trésorière du banc villageois TP Takku Liguèye à Kolda ou elle joue un rôle très important. Oumou vend de l’huile de palme du miel et de la patte d’arachide, elle voudrait y associer la vente de poulets de chaire. Avec les bénéfices du cycle précédent elle a acheté des poussins et a construit un locale pour les abriter. Elle sollicite ce 18ème prêt pour continuer son activité et acheter des aliments pour les poussins. Ce prêt sera remboursé au bout de 6 mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy honey, palm oil, peanut butter, and chicken feed

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophat L., 41, and her husband, Mr. Sarem Saum have been married for twenty years and have six children; three sons and three daughters. Three of her children are in school and the other three children work in a garment factory.  Sarem grows rice on his farm about 7 kilometers from the house. He also does construction work when he is not rice farming. The family lives in an old house about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sophat started her business of selling dessert many years ago. She sells many kinds of Cambodian dessert made from corn, bananas, bean, and sticky rice. She cooks them at home for sell at Prek Phnao Market about five kilometers from her house. Now she is requesting a loan of US$500 to repair her house.

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Bertha Julia

texts.es:
Bertha is 29 years old and lives in the neighborhood of Concepción de María. She is single and has three minor children who are in school.

Bertha’s business is renting rooms and the sale of iron products. She has six years of experience and started with her own money and little merchandise. The loan she is requesting is for the construction of a room to improve the conditions of the clients to whom she rents. In the future she will build her business, give her children an education and have a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Bertha tiene 29 años de edad, habita en el barrio Concepción de Maria y es soltera, tiene tres niños menores de edad que están estudiando. El negocio de doña Bertha es el alquiler de cuartos y venta de productos ferreteros tiene seis años de experiencia e inició con fondos propios y pocas mercancías. Con el dinero que esta solicitando es para la construcción de un cuarto para mejorar más las condiciones de los clientes que tiene alquilando. A futuro es incrementar su negocio, darles educación a sus hijos y tener un nivel de vida mejor.

loans.use: Construction of a room to be rented as living space

loans.name: Israel

texts.es:
Israel began his business because he was an orange picker, a very exhausting job. The picking seasons were extremely hard months, and there were months when he didn't have work. This motivated him to change his job, because his income was not stable. This meant he couldn't provide the basic necessities for his family, and he didn't make a dignified living. He began his business about 20 years ago with much sacrifice, and he began by picking oranges during the day and working in a carpentry shop part of the night. He did this in order to be able to learn the job well. He had to wait about 8 years, and it was then that he became independent. Little by little he achieved success, moving his business forward.

He needs a loan of US $700 that he will repay in 6 months to purchase materials for work, mostly plywood, and to not be waiting to order materials until a client gives him an order, which costs him a lot of time. With your help Israel will be able to grow his business.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer.

Israel inició el negocio porque era trabajador de la pisca de naranja un trabajo muy agotador ya que las temporadas de recoleccion son meses muy pesadas y habia meses que no se tenia trabajo eso lo motivo a cambiar de oficio ya que debido a esto sus ingresos eran inestables y no podia cubrir las necesidades basicas de su familia ademas de tener una vivienda digna. Comenzó su negocio hace aproximadamente 20 años con mucho sacrificio y empeño ya que aparte de piscador de la naranja tambien durante el dia y parte de la noche trabajaba en un taller de carpinteria para poder aprender bien el oficio tuvieron que pasar 8 años aproximadamente y fue entonces cuando se independizoy poco a poco ha logrado sacar adelante su negocio.

El necsita un prestamo por US $700 que pagara en 6 meses para surtir material de trabajo, principalmente de triplay y no estar esperanzado a que el cliente le de anticipos ya que eso le hace perder mucho tiempo. Con tu ayuda Israel hara crecer su negocio.

loans.use: To buy materials for his work

loans.name: Kotankègnè (Rien Ne Nous Est Impossible) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Kotankègnè (Nothing is Impossible for Us) group have an average age of 39, on average 4 children, and are all married. They live in big traditional polygamous families in the Dandila district of the village of Mèfa (fourth economic region of the Republic of Mali, Ségou). They have come together because of bonds of friendship and work. The Bendiya Mèfa association, to which the Kotankègnè group belongs, has had the chance to participate in lots of training sessions organized under the auspices of aid to rural organizations through the rural loan of the NGO Foundation for International Development Africa.

These women sell agricultural products, firewood, condiments, and charcoal. In their search for financial resources, this group, who had worked with several micro-finance institutions, finally decided to join Soro Yiriwaso, which has approved their first group loan request.

With this loan, they are going to buy 7 sacks of peanuts, 3 sacks of millet, 12 wagonloads of firewood, and a substantial quantity of condiments.

They purchase their condiments in Ségou; their cereals and firewood where they live (from rural people who have an authorization to cut wood) and in the surrounding villages such as Douga, Zenguela, Farabougou, Gachi, Siguila et Dialabougou.

The agricultural products and firewood are sold to wholesalers right in the village or sold in the residential neighborhoods of the town of Ségou, for cash, going door-to-door. As for the condiments, they are sold right in Mèfa out of their houses or in the market fairs of surrounding villages.

The clientele is mostly composed of middlemen who come from the big cities and of women. They expect to make a monthly average profit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to make payments on the loan, with the remainder invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

Les membres de Kotankègnè (Rien ne nous est impossible) ont une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans, 4 enfants et toutes mariés vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles polygames dans le quartier Dandila du village de Mèfa (quatrième région économique de la république de Mali, Ségou). Elles se sont regroupées en raison de liens d’amitié et de travail. L’association Bendiya Mèfa à laquelle le groupe Kotankègnè appartient a bénéficié de beaucoup de formations organisées dans le cadre de l’appui aux organisations paysannes à travers le prêt de campagne par l’ ONG FIDA.

Ces femmes exercent le commerce de produits agricoles, du bois de chauffe, des condiments et du charbon de bois. Dans leur recherche de ressources financières ce groupe ayant eu à travailler avec plusieurs institutions de microfinance décida de rejoindre finalement Soro Yiriwaso lequel leur a accorder leur premier prêt de groupe.

Avec ce prêt elles vont acheter 7 sacs d’arachide, 3 sacs de mil, 12 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe et une quantité considérable de condiments alimentaires.

Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments à Ségou ; en céréales et en bois de chauffe sur place (auprès des paysans ayant une autorisation de coupe de bois) et dans les villages aux alentours (tels Douga, Zenguela, Farabougou, Gachi, Siguila et Dialabougou).

Les produits agricoles et le bois de chauffe sont vendus aux grossistes sur place au village ou vendus dans les quartiers de la ville de Ségou au comptant en ambulant. Quant aux condiments ils sont vendus sur place à Mèfa à domicile ou dans les foires des villages environnants.

La clientèle est majoritairement composée de revendeurs venant des grandes villes et les femmes. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans les activités.

loans.use:
Purchase of condiments, cereals, and firewood for re-sale

Achat de condiments, des grains de céréales et du bois de chauffe

loans.name: Enedina

texts.es:
Enedina inicio su negocio para sacar adelante a sus hijos ya que ella es la que se hace cargo de la manutención de sus hijos. Comenzó hace 7 años vendiendo comidas en su casa posteriormente rento un local y se amplio, y poco a poco ha salido adelante.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $350 que pagara en 4 meses para comprar materia prima. Con tu apoyo ella podrá continuar con su negocio.
texts.en:
Enedina started her business to help her children get ahead because she is the one responsible for supporting them. She started seven years ago selling food in her home and later rented a locale, expanded and little by little she has come out ahead. She needs a loan for US$350, which she will repay in four months, to buy ingredients. With your help she will be able to continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients

loans.name: Mrs. Yue Sakhorn's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village loan is taken by thirteen people who live in Svay Mean Leak Village in Kandal Province, Cambodia. 

Mrs. Yue S. was selected by the members to be the village president. She owns a small store in the local village where she sells desserts. Mrs. Yue S. is 57 years old and the mother of a 14-year-old child who attends the local school. 

Her husband, Mr. Tech Banheng, has 1/2 hectare (1.25 acres), on which he cultivates rice to earn a living. He now faces an obstacle because his field is infertile. To solve this problem, his wife is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field and make the crops more productive. 

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term (EoT) loans. Eight members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly-payment loans. Members with end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows the borrower to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Although they are not required to, most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Sreytouch

texts.en: Mrs. Sreytouch C., 39, and her husband, Mr. Kimhoun Hong, 40, live on an island about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Married in 1998, they have one son and three daughters who are all currently studying in the local school. Mrs. Sreytouch learned how to weave from her parents when she was seventeen years old. She has been weaving for over twenty five years, while her husband has been weaving for ten years. They sell their finished products to the trader in the village. Mrs. Sreytouch is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.pt:
Ana Maria M. e natural de Maputo, tem 44 anos de idade, e casada maritalmente, tem 4 filhos, o primeiro tem 25 anos e trabalha na Africa do Sul com 8ª classe concluída, o segundo com 23 também trabalha na Africa do Sul com 9ª classe concluída, o terceiro tem 20 anos e frequenta 9ª classe, o quarto tem 16 anos e frequenta 9ª classe, o ultimo tem 7 anos e frequenta 3ª classe.

Ana estudou ate 4ª classe do antigo sistema e parou de estudar quando começou a fazer negocio a mais de 20 anos atrás, teve a sua infância em Boane e depois foi viver no Bairro do Jardim quando juntou-se maritalmente com o seu marido este que se encontra a trabalhar na Africa do Sul. Basicamente sustenta os seus filhos.

O negocio dela e venda de produtos alimentares o qual faz a mais de 20 anos, onde destaca os seguintes produtos: Amendoim que compra por 490 rands e vende por 1800,00mt e Feijão que compra por 450rands e vende por 1700,00mt, assim tem um rendimento mensal de 8000,00mt liquido e consegue poupar 3500,00mt.

Ana tem plano para um futuro breve de construir algumas dependências para aluguer de quartos de forma aumentar a sua renda familiar.
texts.en:
Ana Maria M. is a native of Maputo, is 44 years old, and is married with five children. Her oldest is 25, finished 8th grade, and works in South Africa. Her second child is 23, finished 9th grade, and also works in South Africa. Her third, 20 years old, attends 9th grade, her fourth, 16, also attends 9th grade, and her youngest, 7, is in 3rd grade. Ana studied until 4th grade (old system) and left her studies when she started her business over 20 years ago. She grew up in Boane, and later moved to Bairro do Jardim when she married her husband, who now works in South Africa. Essentially, she alone supports her children. Her grocery store has been in business for over 20 years, and specializes in these products: peanuts, which she buys for 490 Rands and sells for 1,800 MT, and beans, which she buys for 450 Rands and sells for 1,700 MT. She has a monthly income of 8,000 MT in cash, of which she is able to save 3,500 MT. In the near future, Ana plans to build and rent rooms to augment her family income.

Translated from Portuguese by Steve Fogel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing products for resale

loans.name: Tla

texts.en:
Tla S., 28, lives with her husband and their three children in the Siem Reap province. She is a farmer who makes $1.5 per day. Her husband works as both a farmer and a fisherman, earning on average $2 a day. One of their children is attending school, while the other two remain too young. Farming has been difficult in the past year due to poor weather conditions. Mrs. Tla S. is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase rice seeds and fertilizers for the farm. 

Her husband is pictured.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Etoile Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Etoile (composé de 5 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans avec en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Hamdallaye dans des foyers polygames dans la ville de Sikasso.(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente de bananes en plus, elles font la vente du bois de chauffe, des boissons non alcoolisées et  la restauration.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle les membres de ce groupe ont intégré l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle, ils sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Le prêt précédent a été correctement dénoué.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 24 régimes de bananes, 18 casiers de boissons non alcoolisées, 2 chargements de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 3 paquets d’ingrédients divers (condiments alimentaires) et un sac de riz. Elles s’approvisionnent soit à Bamako (capitale du Mali),  ou sur place à Sikasso ville  et dans les villages environnants. Les produits sont vendus en détail et au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20. 500 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ambitionnent très prochainement l’aménagement du restaurant, aller faire le chargement de camionnettes en régimes de bananes jusque dans les plantations, ouverture d’un dépôt de boissons etc.
texts.en:
The members of the group Etoile (composed of five married women) average 32 years of age and two children. They reside in the Hamdallaye district in polygamous homes in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do different commercial work but predominant is the sale of bananas. In addition, they sell firewood and soft drinks and do catering.

In order to satisfy their customers, the group members have joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loans have been correctly settled. They plan to use this loan to buy 24 bunches of bananas, 18 cases of soft drinks, 2 truck-loads of firewood, 2 packets of various ingredients (condiments), and 1 sack of rice. They stock up either in Bamako (capital of Mali) or locally in Sikasso and surrounding villages. The goods are sold retail for cash in the different marketplaces of Sikasso and in the district to customers composed of women and men.

The group members each hope to realize a monthly profit of 20,500 francs CFA that will be used to provide for their families and to invest the rest in their businesses. Their ambition is to fix up a restaurant very shortly, to load up trucks with bananas from plantations, and to open an outlet for beverages, etc.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bananas, firewood, beverages, and ingredients for catering

loans.name: Eliaishi

texts.en:
Eliaishi  a member of Wema group in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha. She has been a business woman for 6 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $110. Every day she works at her business from 8am to 12pm. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  

Eliaishi is 25 years old, married, and has one child: ages 1. She also cares for one additional dependant.

loans.use: To buy more items in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Freida

texts.en:
Freda S., 41, is married with five children. She has five years of experience in the cattle farm/plantation business. She sells to the general public/villagers four days per week.

She has had six previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 1250 Tala (about $520).

SPBD loans are Freda’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Freida's loan will be used to buy chemicals, knives and sacks of fertilizer for her plantation business.

loans.use: To buy chemicals, knives and sacks of fertilizer

loans.name: Mr. Reaksmi Kung Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of twenty-one members, is located in Preak Ta Thok village in Kandal province. The members plan to use the loan that they obtain for different purposes. The members selected Mr. Reaksmi K. as the village bank president.  He is a hard-working man because he breeds pigs and uses rice to make wine to sell. Since his breeding pigs business is doing well, he wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets to add to his business. His wife, Mrs. Phal Malay, is employed in a garment factory. Mr. Reaksmi K. is 27 years old and the father of a child who is enrolled in the local school. Mrs. Sokthet H. did not come to take a loan but her husband did, so he is shown in the picture instead.  

Seven members in this group have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets

loans.name: Tulafileka F.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Tulafileka F. C. from Tukuyu. She is married with four children between the ages of 1 and 13. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent, an orphan whose parents died of HIV. 

Tulafileka has been running a grocery business since 2007. A genge (grocery store) is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient. 

Tulafileka works at her business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Tulafileka currently earns about 95USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 625USD in order to purchase more sugar, beans, salt, cooking oil, rice, and wheat flour in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business. Tulafileka thanks you for your support!

About SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and therefore they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.
