She is applying for her first loan. She plans to use part of the loan to buy farm inputs and other items to use in business. 

She intends to use the additional income from the proceeds of this loan to buy cattle for fattening and to pay her children's school fees. She hopes to develop her business and to be financially stable in the future

loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Daysi Tatiana

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal María Del Carmen se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi (Portoviejo). Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla, ciudad de clima fresco y con muchos atractivos turísticos naturales propios de la zona.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Daysi, tiene 24 años de edad está casada y de  esta relación tiene dos niñas de 9 y 4 años de edad la mayor estudian en escuela. Su esposo es comerciante.
 
Ella realiza el crédito  para ayudar a su esposo con su negocio, él se dedica a la venta de pescado,  todos los días en la madrugada él se desplaza hasta las playas para comprar el mejor pescado para luego llevarlo a Montecristi lugar que recorre en un triciclo para poder vender todo lo que lleva y con esto lograr ganar lo suficiente para que no falte nada en el hogar. Lleva como 13 años en este negocio y le va bien a pesar de que a veces es escaso el pescado.

Este crédito es para comprar pescado. Lleva seis ciclos en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le brindan los créditos.
 
Su sueño es que su esposo compre un carro para que realice sus ventas.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the 'María del Carmen' community bank meet in Montecristi canton (Portoviejo).  This is the home of the famous Panama hat.  It is a cold-climate city and there are many natural tourist attractions in the area. 

Here we meet Daysi.  She is 24 years old, married, and has two daughters from this relationship who are 9 and 4 years old.  Her eldest attends school.  Her husband is a salesman.

Daysi is taking out a loan to help her husband with his fish selling business.  Early every morning, he goes to the beach to buy the best fish which he then transports to Montecristi, on a three-wheeled vehicle, to sell.  This allows him to earn enough that his family don't want for anything.  He has been in this business for 13 years and it is doing well in spite of the fact that fish is sometimes scarce.

This loan will be used to buy fish.  Daysi has been a member of her community bank for six loan cycles and she likes it for the help she gets from the loans.  Her dream is for her husband to buy a car for his work.

loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Mrs. Lay, 64, is in the business of raising pigs. She has been engaged in this business, from which she is able to yield an income of $2.00 per day, since 2004. She has a life partner in her husband, who earns a living by selling the firewood, using animal’s force to haul his firewood-trailer. 

Presently, Mrs. Lay needs some funds in the sum of KHR3,800,000 from HKL and Kiva to purchase an additional buffalo to support her husband’s business. This loan will help her family’s living conditions improve. She wants to expand her pig-raising business in the future. Now she lives with 3 single children and her husband in Baray district.

loans.use: to purchase an additional buffalo to support her husband’s business.

loans.name: Wilmer

texts.es: Wilmer, de 31 años vive en casa de sus padres junto a su pareja Yasmina de 23 años y su pequeña hija Angeli, a quien desea un mejor futuro. Hace 08 meses que Wilmer, empezó a trabajar como conductor para una empresa de taxis. Desde entonces, Wilmer se levanta muy temprano para poder ir a su trabajo, él hace transporte dentro de su localidad. Lo que mas le gusta de trabajo es llevar a la gente y conversar con los pasajeros sobre las experiencias que cada uno de ellos tienen. Con el tiempo desea abrir un cafetín en el colegio para que su pareja pueda trabajar junto a su pequeña hija y así ayudar con los gastos de su familia. Este será su préstamo número 04 con MFP; por tanto espera de su colaboración para continuar con su objetivo; asimismo se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con el pago de sus cuotas como en anteriores créditos que tuvo. En su banco comunal es una persona responsable y solidario con sus compañeros. Con los 2,000 nuevos soles, invertirá abriendo un cafetín en el colegio de su localidad y comprará productos como: galletas, caramelos, gaseosas, etc.
texts.en:
Wilmer, 31, lives in his parents’ house with his spouse, Yasmina, 23, and his little girl, Angeli, that he wants a better future for.  

Eight months ago Wilmer started working as a driver for a taxi company.  Since then, Wilmer rises very early to go to work; he provides transportation within his location.  What he likes best about his work is moving people and chatting with his passengers about the experiences each one of them has had.  In time, he wants to open a snack bar in a school so that his spouse can work near their little girl and help with household expenses.

This will be MFP loan #4 and he hopes he’ll get your cooperation to reach his goal; he promises to continue making his payments like he’s done with previous loans.  He is a responsible, supportive member of his communal bank.  He will use the 2000 new soles to open a snack bar at his local school.  He will buy merchandise like: cookies, candy, soft-drinks, etc.

loans.use: to buy cookies, candy and soft-drinks.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née le 04 Mars 1975 à Loutana Préfecture de Sikasso, Madame Mariam  est mariée et mère de 7 enfants et réside avec son époux et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Sanoubougou I Kapel Kourou, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso.
Après plusieurs activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée depuis plus de dix années à cette activité de petit commerce notamment à l’achat et à la vente d’habillements  de pagnes wax, sacs à main, tissus brodé, etc. Elle achète ses marchandises à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) avant de les revendre à sa place au marché de leur localité où ses marchandises sont beaucoup sollicitées de sa clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes de ménages et  de revendeuses.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus d’une année. Elle a bénéficié deux crédits  tous correctement remboursés.  Ainsi, elle sollicite un troisième crédit pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter,  25 pièces de pagnes wax, 15 complets de tissus brodés et 24 sacs à main. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce premier crédit un bénéfice mensuel de 180 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born March 4th, 1975, in Loutana, Sikasso Prefecture, Mariam is married and a mother of seven.  She lives with her husband and their children in a traditional extended family in Sanoubougou I Kapel Kourou, one of the neighborhoods on the outskirts of the city of Sikasso.
Over ten years ago, after several unsuccessful businesses, she started this small-scale business, specifically buying and selling wax print fabric for traditional wrap skirts, handbags, embroidered fabric, etc.  She purchases her merchandise at Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) before reselling them at her stall in the market of their town, where her products are highly sought-after by her customers, consisting largely of housekeepers and retail saleswomen.
Over a year ago she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, in hopes of better satisfying her growing clientele.  She has been able to take advantage of two loans, both of which have been fully paid back.  She is therefore asking for a third loan to increase her business capital in order to purchase 25 lengths of wax print skirt fabric, 15 outfits of embroidered fabric and 24 handbags.  She plans on using this loan to generate a monthly profit of 180,000 CFA francs, which will essentially be used to contribute to family expenses, pay interest on her loan and invest in her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothing

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is 40 years old and lives in Olo, Siquijor, Philippines.  She is married and has two school-age children.  Delia sells fish in the market everyday to earn a living.  She earns approximately PHP 2,500 each month doing this type of work.  

She has requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase fresh catches of fish from fishermen and to deliver them to the market.  Delia has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for six months.  In the future, Delia hopes to have savings for the better education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase fresh catches of fish from fishermen and to deliver them to the market

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is married and has four children ranging from eight and twenty-five years of age. She describes herself as a focused and generous woman. She has been selling maize and beans for the last two years. In addition, she also sells chickens and milk to add to her sources of income. Jane's business challenge is the high cost of maize. She will use the loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more maize. Her dream and hope is buy a center for distributing maize in major towns in the next five years.

loans.use: To buy more  maize to sell.

loans.name: La Nueva Esperanza 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Emilio is one of the members of the group La Nueva Esperanza (New Hope 2 & 3). This group is comprised of micro-entrepreneurs dedicated to selling clothing, natural goods, shoes, working as educators, and other professions. Members work in the city of San Pedro de Macoris, a city famous for its athletes and sugar industry. Emilio is receiving his ninth loan, almost five years after receiving his first. He has successfully invested and repaid his previous loans. Emilio runs a business where he sells miscellaneous items such as shoes, cosmetics, clothing, and other products.

Emilio is planning to use his loan to buy clothing, cosmetics, and shoes. He will save his profits to continue building his house. Emilio enjoys listening to music, and his goal is to faithfully repay his loans to continue investing in his business. His dream is to improve his social condition and to buy a large vehicle, like a truck or a pick-up truck.

loans.use: to buy shoes, cosmetics, clothing, and other items

loans.name: Eusebio

texts.es: Eusebio, tiene 30 años de edad es bachiller, soltero sin hijos trabaja como agricultor y como comerciante de ropa, vendiendo cinco días de cada semana trasladando su mercadería de pueblo en pueblo en su humilde vehículo, como agricultor tiene plantaciones de naranja, mandarina y yuca en su propio terreno agrícola ubicado en sindicato siglo xx, se dedica a la agricultura los otros dos días restantes de la semana aprovecha para mantener y cosechar sus naranjas , mandarina y yuca siempre trabaja solo y no cuenta con la ayuda de nadie para mantener sus plantaciones y cuando estén listos para su comercialización los comercializa siempre en la zona local, el sr. Eusebio desea mejorar sus ingresos económicos para ello necesita la ayuda de este crédito, porque quiere ampliar sus cítricos (naranja y mandarina) para mejorar el nivel de vida que tiene mejorando también su producción y calidad de sus cítricos para así poder quizás formar una familia.
texts.en:
Eusebio, 30, is a high school graduate, single and has no children.  He works as a farmer and also sells clothing.  Five days a week he goes from village to village in his modest vehicle to sell his merchandise.  As a farmer he grows oranges, tangerines and yucca plant on his own farmland which is in the "Siglo XX" trade union area.  On weekends, he takes care of his crops and always works alone, with no one to help maintain the plantations.  When the crops are ready for harvest he sells them in the local area.

Eusebio wants to improve his income and is requesting a loan.  He plans to expand his citrus crop (oranges and tangerines) to improve his lifestyle.  He also wants to improve citrus production and quality, so he can form a family one day.

loans.use: To buy supplies to increase citrus production.

loans.name: Rosemary's Group

texts.en:
Rosemary’s group has six farmers, each of whom is a group leader for several other farmers. They are located in Kakamega North District.  The group leaders in this group represent a total of 52 individual farmers (not pictured). Each of the farmers is asking for an average loan of 5,349 Kenya shillings. Each of them will use his or her loan to purchase a One Acre Fund package, sufficient to cultivate one-quarter acre of maize and one-quarter acre of sorghum or millet.

As the representative of this Kiva group comprised of farmer-leaders, Rosemary is pictured on the right of the group with her hand raised.  Rosemary is a reliable member of the community.  She is married and has two children.  She is 56 years old, and she has been working as a farmer for the past 21 years to support her family.  In addition to this, Rosemary is very active in her community, including involvement in the women's group and savings group.  The 2013 Long Rains season won’t be Rosemary’s first season with One Acre Fund.  She first joined One Acre Fund in 2011.  She has continued working with One Acre Fund, in order to get the best seed prices, to learn new farming methods, and to get fertilizer and hybrid seeds.  She described her harvest last year as "Good."  She hopes to continue working with One Acre Fund and to continue enjoying the success she has been having with the One Acre Fund farm packages. 

As an active member in her community, Rosemary also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative, because she wants to help more farmers.  Rosemary plans on using future profits from the harvest to send children to school and to save for the future.  She has improved her life by working with One Acre Fund, because she has more farm training and she is able to feed the family. 

Rosemary and her group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers, with the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings along to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

The field officer is included in the photo with the farmer-leaders, and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Hamida's Group

texts.en:
Hamida is a member of this group from Iraq. Hamida is 55 years old widow mother of two . She is one of the many entrepreneur Iraqi women that started their own business to meet the financial needs of their families.
She has twelve years of experience with her sewing business activity. When she heard about Izdiharona's qard hassan product (without interest) for widow women she took a loan to buy iron and sewing machine to increase her products.
She is aiming to develop her business and increase her profits by open big factory and hire jobless women.
They preferred to blur their face for cultural reason.

loans.use: A portion of Hamida's Group's $ 3,000 loan helps a member to buy iron and  sewing machine.

loans.name: Lirios Group

texts.es:
Nieves es una mujer de 47 años de edad, soltera, tiene 5 hijos de 20, 23, 26, 28 y 29 años, y su negocio es la venta de comida: ‘Patasca’.
Ella es emprendedora, independiente y muy optimista. Su negocio lo realiza en el barrio ‘Jhonny Fernandez’ caracterizado por albergar a decenas de familias sobrevivientes del desborde del rio la década anterior, hoy en día convertida en la ciudadela manufacturera de la ciudad, de clima cálido tropical muy húmedo con una temperatura máxima de 35 grados centígrados.
Nieves es de tez morena, cabello largo y físico robusto (sentada la segunda de la derecha, viste blusa animal print gris y negro), Su lengua materna es el Guaraní que habla dentro de su entorno familiar y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza, su vida la comparte con sus 2 hijos menores que trabajan, el resto tienen su propias familias, viven en un cuarto alquilado construido de ladrillo con techo de calamina y piso de cemento que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. El deseo de mejorar su negocio la llevó a liderar la banca de emprendimiento, los negocios de los socios son; confección de sábanas, venta de ropa de segunda mano, venta de productos naturales para la salud, librería, tienda de barrio, venta de pollo frito, verdulería y cerrajería. Su negocio es la venta de comida, ella se especializa en la preparación de ‘Patasca’ se sirve como una sopa espesa, la característica principal es que se prepara a base de cabeza de cerdo y se cocina 12 horas al fuego, se empieza desde la madrugada para tenerlo listo a primeras horas de la mañana, “Es una comida para degustarse por la mañana, bien temprano, las personas lo consumen como un remedio para la resaca…” comenta. Su negocio es exitoso porque es la única comida de este tipo que se encuentra a primeras horas de la mañana. La ventaja de su negocio es que sus hijos se turnan para ayudarle por la madrugada, la desventaja es la falta de insumos de cocina para el trabajo diario. Su sueño es ampliar el ambiente de su negocio para mejorar sus ventas, ella desea comprar insumos de cocina como aceite, verduras, arroz, fideo y carne. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 5 años que realiza esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Nieves solicita un préstamo para comprar insumos de cocina para cocinar ‘Patasca’.

loans.use: para comprar insumos de cocina para cocinar ‘Patasca’.

loans.name: Kokouvi

texts.en:
Born in 1985, Kokouvi D. finished middle school in Tsévié before entering an apprenticeship because his parent no longer had the money for more schooling. He currently lives in Kpatéfi, where he manages his uncle’s shop selling general grocery items. He is single with no children, and his socio-economic situation is nothing to envy. Mastering his work and having an instinct for management, he would like to be on his own.

To achieve this, he is requesting a loan of $750 for opening a shop and establishing his own business. The loan will allow him to take care of educating his little brothers and to ensure that things improve, particularly the lives of his elderly parents.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Né en 1985, Monsieur D. Kokouvi a fait ses études primaires et secondaires à Tsévié avant d’entrée en apprentissage car les parents n’ont plus de moyens pour lui assurer sa scolarité. Actuellement, il vit à Kpatéfi où il gère une boutique de vente d’alimentation générale d’un oncle. Célibataire sans enfant, sa situation socio économique n’est pas à envier. Maîtrisant ses activités et ayant le sens d’une bonne gestion, il souhaite aujourd’hui mener ses propres affaires.

A cet effet, il sollicite un crédit de $750 qui va lui permettre d’ouvrir une boutique et s’installer à son propre compte. Ce qui permettre de s’occuper de la formation de ses jeunes frères et d’assurer de l’amélioration des conditions surtout de ses parents en âge avancé.

loans.use: To open his own shop

loans.name: Wartisem

texts.en: W. is a 45-year-old mother with one child, aged 20. She has been selling cooked foods in a small restaurant for 20 years. She usually earns $10 per day. She opens her small restaurant from 5pm – 2am everyday. Her husband, Dakir, is a fisherman. He sells fish in the fish market, earning $2 per day. She is a member of MBK and requests a $50 loan to expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Small Restaurant

loans.name: Kayi

texts.en:
Born in 1971 in Aklakou, Mrs A. Kayi is married and the mother of four children. She is also responsible for two grand-children. Her daily activity is the sale of peanuts and also cereals. Nicknamed "Mother AZITO", Mrs Kayi started her business from her small peanut field. With 12 years of experience in this area, "Mother AZITO" knows her business well. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to be able to buy peanuts from other growers and resell them. The profits will allow her to provide for the numerous and increasing needs of her family.

Translated from French by Susan Bell, Kiva Volunteer.

Née en 1971 à Aklakou, Madame A. Kayi est mariée et mère de quatre enfants. Elle compte aujourd’hui à sa charge, outre ses enfants, deux petits fils. La vente de céréales et surtout d’arachide est son activité quotidienne. Surnommé « Maman AZITO », Mme Kayi a commencé son commerce à partir de son petit champ d’arachide. Douze ans déjà dans cette activité « Maman AZITO » cerne tous les rouages du commerce. Elle sollicite un crédit de $1000 pour pouvoir aller dans les zones de production d’arachide, en acheter et venir les revendre. Les bénéfices lui permettront de subvenir aux nombreux besoins qui ne cessent de s’alourdir dans la famille.

loans.use: puchase, storage and resale of peanuts

loans.name: Ahou

texts.en:
K. Ahou E. is a dynamic 30-year-old woman. She lives in Port-Bouët, a township in the southern area of Abidjan. E. is a tailor and she has been working for herself for more than 6 years. She operates in the Port-Bouët open market where she makes children's garments.

E. wants to acquire electric sewing machine and purchase a stock of textiles to make school uniforms for September and October. E. joined the AE&I microcredit program in June, 2006 and has benefited from a micro-loan that she reimbursed in good manner. E. is well organized and ambitious.

loans.use: Konan Ahou Eugenie will use the loan  acquire an electric sewing machine

loans.name: Betty

texts.es:
Betty Adriazola, is separated and has 2 children. She is a part of the association Wara de Villa Tejada in the city of El Alto. Her main activity is the sales of every day grocery items in the zone of La Ceja in El Alto. Generally she sells by request, to people she knows and trusts, to whom she sells on credit and afterwards charges a small amount of interest.

Betty started with Pro Mujer, requesting a small credit that enabled her to buy a few grocery items in this way, and generate resources by selling them. At this time, she will use the capital to increase her merchandise, taking advantage of wholesale prices which are definitely the most profitable with sales.

Betty A., separada y madre de dos hijos, pertenece a la asociación Wara de Villa Tejada en El Alto, su principal actividad es la venta y comercialización de víveres en la zona de la Ceja de El Alto, generalmente ella trabaja a pedido, entre aquellas personas ya conocidas y de confianza, a quienes vende al crédito y posteriormente cobra con un pequeño interés. Betty se inició con Pro Mujer, solicitando un crédito pequeño que le permitió la compra de algunos víveres y de esta manera generar recursos tras la venta de los mismos. Actualmente, Betty se precisa de capital para poder incrementar su mercadería, principalmente aprovechar la compra al por mayor, que definitivamente es más rentable al momento de la venta. CREDITO : $1500

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: To buy more merchandise and take advantage of wholesale prices.

loans.name: Silva

texts.pt:
Silva U. was born in the province of Sanga in Niassa, on January 30th 1967. He supports a family of 5. He was raised by his family with his twin brother. When he was 14 years old left home to join the military. He received a scholarship to go to Hungary where he finished High School and studied Economy and management. Years later he returned and started working for CMGM. He was introduced to lhuvuku by friends.

He joined the credit program hoping to improve his home. Silva works at CMGM and pays for the schooling of his children, supports his family and pays for the construction of the house. With the loan of 60.000mt, he plans on finishing the wall and painting the home In the future he wants to request another loan to pay for his twin brother’s wedding.

Translated from Portuguese Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localizaçao: Maputo matola texlom Actividade: Habitaçao Valor empréstimo: 60.000,00MTN Aplicação do empréstimo: Compra de material de construçao Início: 06-11-07 Fim:28-02-09 Silva U., nascido em Sanga Provincia de Niassa a 40 anos aos 30 de Janeiro de 1967, sustenta 5 pessoas e reside na casa propria que adquiriu em 2002. Cresceu e viveu num ambiente familiar onde tina 10 irmaos e sendo ele gémeo. Quando tinha 14 anos separa-se da familia para cumprir o serviço militar obrigatório a vida foi dificil nos primeiros dias mas porque o estado organizava-se, sensibilizava e encorajava os novos soldados em prol da defesa do país, acabou se adaptando e é assim que o tempo foi passando. Teve uma bolsa de estudos para hungria onde ,prosseguiu com os estudos fez o ensino médio e depois licenciou-se em economia e gestao.

Anos mais tarde voltou ao pais e foi afecto no CMGM como gestor administrativo . ate que um dia ouviu falar da lhuvuku através de colegas seus que trabalhavam numa escola de fuzileiros navais. Decidiu também procurar a instituição e solicitar um emprestimo para melhorar a sua casa. Assim durante a sua actividade não tem tido dificuldades porque esta la a esposa a velar por tudo que lhes diz respeito, assim como tem controlado a obra e dar o relatório diariamente ao seu esposo porque este sai de muito cedo de casa e volta bastante tarde devido aos estudos no perodio pós laboral. Actualmente para além de trabalhar no C.M.G.M, faz assinatura de contas em varia instituições e que com o salario consegue pagar os seus estudos ,escola dos filhos e manter a casa assim como poupar para a obra.. Com o empréstimo de 60.000,00 ( secenta mil meticais)pretende concluir o murro e fazer a pintura de casa. A sua perspectiva futura e terminar o crédito e fazer um outro empréstimo para fazer um casamento comum com o seu irmão gémeo.

loans.use: to buy construction material to finish up his house

loans.name: Mamur

texts.en: Mamur R. lives in Mastchoh. Mamur R. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007 and he recommends himself as a serious and strongly-motivated client. His loan sums are permanently increased which shows his business's stability and his income increase. He has the wide-side business including livestock raising and selling, milk production and work out. He dreams of purchasing a horn pedigree bull and a milk cow for further meat and milk and sour-milk goods production (its supply to the bazaars and his family is secure by the milk and sour products). He plans to include in the assortment the following milk and sour products: pasteurized milk, sour milk, sour cream, curd and etc. Now he requires a loan in 1600 STJ for a horn pedigree bull and a pedigree milk cow which will allow him to significantly increase his family's income and will also permits him to plan further business and a wider assortment of milk goods.

loans.use: Mamur would like to purchase a horn pedigree bull and a pedigree milk cow.

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: Mrs. Suon I., 42, works wI. her husband on a piece of land growing various kinds of vegetables, such as tomatoes, cucumber, chili, radish, and lettuce. WI. this business, the couple can collectively earn around $3 each day from selling their output to market. Additionally, this couple has six children. One of them is employed in a factory; three are construction workers and the rest are married and stay separately. Mrs. Suon I. hopes to use this loan to purchase another piece of farmland to enable her to expand a number of her crops.Her current farmland is quite narrow so it’s so hard to grow more crops to meet her client's demand.

loans.use: To purchase another piece of farmland to expand her crops.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia D. D. T. has a general store in the town of Jepelacio, San Martin. She started the store in 1988 as an investment to help her family. Amelia is friendly, charismatic, and loves to work. The store is now the largest in Jepelacio. She sells a large variety of goods, ranging from baby products, medicines, clothes, and school supplies.

Amelia is 60 years old, happily married, and has 4 children. All of her children are adults so she now focuses on helping her grandchildren as much as possible. Amelia is so happy and proud she started her business and what she has accomplished. Over the years, she has maD. many friends and now has a voice in her community.

A member of the community bank Mujeres Responsables, Amelia is requesting a loan of $625 (s/1800) to repay over 4 months. With the loan, she would like to stock her store with school uniforms and school supplies as the new school year begins soon.

loans.use: She would like to stock her store with school uniforms and school supplies.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence I. is from Edo State, Nigeria, and she is married with 6 children. She is 40 years old. She sews and sells clothes. She has been in business since 1993. She needs the loan amount of $875 to buy clothing materials for sale.

loans.use: To buy clothing materials for sale

loans.name: Barrio El Calvario Ii Group

texts.es:
Within this communal bank, one can find determined women with the entrepreneurial spirit very typical of businesswomen from the coast of Guatemala. All of the women belonging to this bank have a least two businesses.

They invest the money borrowed in different economic ventures like breeding bulls and pigs and selling chicken, vegetables, baked goods and other foods. The also sell firewood, cosmetics and heliconia leaves (used to make tamales).

It was impressive to see the entire group of women so decided about how they would be using the money that they were borrowing. Norma M. commented that she was going to use a part of her loan to sell cosmetics while the other part would be invested in fruit to sell in the market. Juana S. said that as soon as she received her loan, she was going to purchase 300 kg of chicken to sell in the market. María P., like the large majority of the group, was going to buy 150 bunches of heliconia leaves to then sell to distributors. While the women sell one bunch of leaves for seven quetzals, a distributor can sell in the cities for double the price. María P. was going to invest her money in her tortilla business and in the purchase of firewood.

When asked why they like to work with Friendship Bridge, the women said that it was primarily because it gives them a chance to save money. The inability to save is one of the reasons people can’t get out of poverty. Additionally, they said that the low interest and the timeframe the institution offered for repaying the loans help them with their businesses. Also, working under the bank’s methodology is something they like very much.

The women believe that within the Barrio El Calvario Communal Bank they are all equal. Not only that, but there is a lot of communication and understanding within the communal bank. It seems that working with Friendship Bridge has changed their lives. They are very grateful to the institution and to those who invest in them through Kiva because people have believed in them. They are sure that they will not let us down. That’s why helping this and many other groups of women is important, because one gives them a chance and a ray of hope.

Translated form Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Dentro de este banco comunal uno puede encontrar mujeres corajudas y con una visión empresarial muy característica de las empresarias de la costa de Guatemala. Todas las clientas dentro de este banco tienen dos negocios como mínimo.

Ellas invierten su crédito en distintas actividades económicas, tales como la crianza de toros y cerdos, venta de pollo, venta de comidas, venta de verduras, venta de leña, venta ambulante de cosméticos, panadería y la venta de hojas de mashan (las cuales son usadas para envolver los tamales).

Fue impresionante ver a todo un grupo de mujeres tan decididas en que utilizar el préstamos que se les iba a otorgar. Norma M., comentó que ella iba a usar parte de su préstamo para la venta de cosméticos que los iba a vender de manera ambulante, mientras que la otra parte la iba a invertir en la compra de fruta para venderla en el mercado. Juana S., dijo que a penas recibía su préstamo lo iba a invertir en la compra de tres quintales de pollos destazados para su venta en el mercado. María P., como la gran mayoría del grupo, iba a comprar 150 racimos de hojas de mashan para luego venderlo a los intermediaros. Ellas venden un racimo a siete quetzales, mientras que un intermediario puede llegar a venderlo en las ciudades por el doble del precio. María P., va a invertir su crédito en su tortilleria y en la compra de leña.

Cuando se les pregunto porque les gusta trabajar con Friendship Bridge ellas comentaron que era primordialmente porque les daba un espacio para ahorrar. La falta de capacidad de ahorrar es uno de los motivos por los cuales las personas no pueden salir de la pobreza. Adicionalmente, dijeron que los bajos intereses y el plazo que les ofrecía la institución las ayudaba con su negocio. También, trabajar bajo metodología de bancos comunales les gusta mucho.

Las señoras opinan que dentro del banco comunal Barrio el Calvario todas son iguales. No solo eso, sino que hay mucha comunicación y comprensión dentro del banco comunal. Al parecer trabajar con Friendship Bridge les ha cambiado la vida. Ellas agradecen mucho a la institución y a las personas que invierten en ellas desde Kiva por que confiaron en ellas y están seguras de no nos van a defraudar. Es por eso que seguir apoyando a este y a muchos gruP. de mujeres es importante, ya que uno les da un respiro y una luz de esperanza.

loans.use: Breeding bulls and pigs; sale of chicken, vegetables, baked goods and other foods; sale of firewood, cosmetics and heliconia leaves

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas O. is 40 years old, married with 5 children. She sells local gin and palm oil. She hails from Edo State, Nigeria and needs a loan $350 to buy more palm oil to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more oil and local gin to sell

loans.name: Ema Laufiso's Group

texts.en:
The seven members of this group from Savaii work in their different farming businesses. They are one of SPBD's new groups and they attend their weekly meetings and save both in their individual passbooks and in their group savings account. They are looking forward to their next loan for their children's school fees and for home improvements.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural equipment and supplies.

loans.name: Roldan

texts.es:
The sale of churros is the daily activity of señor Roldan who works hard and smoothly to get ahead. He gets up very early to prepare and sell his sweets. Roldan is a very determined man, but above all kind and jovial with is customers. At 43 years of age, he is the father of 5 children with three of them who are already independent and taking care of the last two. They study and are the motivation for don Roldan to continue growing to provide them with what is necessary for them to be decent men. His wife, señora Enith, also works independently and supports him in his decisions. Roldan wants to prepare a place to give his clients attention that could have a mat or branch roof that will protect them from the weather. Then he also wants to enlarge his business and later he would like to buy another cart to make the sweets and that way generate work for those who need it since it is a dessert that is in great demand in his zone. However, to make this father's goal a reality, he needs an amount of money that he is asking you for as a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

La venta de churros es la actividad diaria que tiene el señor Roldan, quien trabaja duro y parejo por seguir adelante. Se levanta muy temprano para preparar y vender su dulce. Roldan es un hombre muy decidido, sobre todo amable y jovial con sus clientes. A sus 43 años es padre de 5 hijos, siendo tres de ellos ya independientes, quedando los dos últimos a su cargo, ellos estudian y son el motivo de don Roldan de seguir surgiendo para brindarles lo necesario para que logren ser hombres de bien, su esposa la señora Enith quien trabaja independientemente lo apoya en sus decisiones.Roldan quiere acondicionar un lugar para la atención a sus clientes, que pueda contar con techo de estera o ramas que los proteja del clima, desde luego también desea crecer en su negocio ya que posteriormente quiere comprarse otro carrito para la elaboración de este dulce y así generar trabajo a quien lo necesite ya que es un postre que tiene mucha acogida en su zona, sin embargo para hacer realidad el objetivo de este padre necesita de una cantidad de dinero, que es la que solicita en préstamo a ustedes.

loans.use: Acquire a place for his clients to stay while they consume his product and a new cart in which to make the sweets that he sells.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.fr:
Mrs. Jacqueline A. was born on 2 October 1962 in Cotonou. Divorced, she is the mother of two children, both educated. Mrs. Jacqueline A. has been selling ready-to-eat meals at the Cotonou hall of arts and culture since 1 January 2008. She has 15 years of experience in the sale of food. She sells rice, beans, boiled maize flour paste, and cooked yams. She is asking for this loan with the hope of better satisfying her customers, composed mostly of visitors to the hall of arts.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Dame A. Jacqueline est née le 02 Octobre 1962 à Cotonou. Divorcée, elle est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Dame A. Jacqueline vend du repas prêt à manger au hall des arts et de la culture de Cotnou depuis le 01 Janvier 2008. Elle a 15 ans d'expérience dans la vente de nourriture. Elle vend du riz, du haricot, de la pâte de farine de maïs bouillie et d'igname cuite. Elle sollicite ce prêt dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle composée pour sa majorité des visiteurs de hall des arts.

loans.use: To buy one 25 kg bag of rice, 25 kg of beans, and various condiments

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Abra A. tient depuis 3 ans une boutique d’alimentation générale à Kpalimé, une ville située à environ 120 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Elle est âgée de 55 ans, mariée e mère de 5 enfants. Elle espère par ce crédit approvisionner sa boutique en achetant des sacs de riz, des cartons de sucres, de laits et autres boîtes de conserves. Cet approvisionnement va entraîner une augmentation des ventes et par conséquent une hausse des gain ; ce qui lui permettra de bien subvenir aux besoins de la famille
texts.en:
For three years, Abra A. has been tending a general store in Kpalimé, a town located about 120 km from Lomé, the capital of Togo. She is 55, married, and the mother of 5 children. She hopes to use this loan to replenish the inventory of her store by buying sacks of rice, cases of sugar, milk, and other tinned foods. This improved range of goods will lead to increased sales and thus, an increased profit, which will allow her to better support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sacks of rice, cases of sugar, milk, and other tinned goods

loans.name: Aqil

texts.en:
Aqil H. is only 20 but he already owns of a small business. His primary activity and only source of income is selling foodstuff like pastries, cookies, candies, condensed milk, tea, caned meat, mayonnaise, soft drinks, and other items in a store that he rents. Aqil started his business in the beginning of 2008 and now his business going very well. Because of his personality and easy-going character, he has gained the respect of a wide variety of clients. He is very polite and his store is very popular with local residents, whose patronage allows him to earn a good income for his family. Aqil covers the needs of his old parents who are on a pension and his brothers and sisters, who are students. 

Aqil has applied for a loan of $1000 USD and will use the loan to buy more items to sell. This will allow him to earn more and meet the needs of his family.  Aqil thanks you for your support and promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en: Roselyn, who bakes snacks such as egg rolls, meat pies, and fish rolls in her house, is 45 years old and married with five children. Very determined to eradicate her family’s poverty and increase the prosperity of her business, Roselyn is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of flour, vegetable oil and one oven so that she can continue to develop her enterprise and meet customer demand. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders and LAPO MICROFINANCE.

loans.use: To buy flour, vegetable oil and one oven for her business

loans.name: Luisa Amanda

texts.es: La Sr. Luisa de 43 años de edad, casada,  habita en reparto España un barrio de la capital de Managua, su esposo trabaja vendiendo autos usado. Doña Luisa tiene 4 años de vender fritanga por la noche, alquila teléfono y ofrecer clases de danzas a niños y adultos. Siendo una forma más de generar ayuda económica para su casa y así cubrir las necesidades. Inicio su negocio con lo que ganaba como profesora de danza en su casa de habitación. Sus planes son aumentar sus ventas de fritangas con nueva variedad de comida para vender. Agracia a los prestamos de Afodenic lograra comprar en mayores cantidades y  eso le generar mayor ganancia. Dándole un mejor futuro a su familia.
texts.en:
Luisa is 43 years old, married, and lives in Reparto España, a neighborhood in the capital of Managua. Her husband sells used cars. For four years, Luisa has sold fried snacks at night, rented telephones, and offered dance classes to children and adults. This has been a way to generate financial support for her household and cover the necessities. She started her business with the money she earned as a dance instructor in her home. Her plans are to increase her sales of fried snacks by selling a new type of food. Thanks to the Afodenic loans she will be able to buy in larger quantities, and this will generate greater profits for her, providing a better future for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy meats and products to sell

loans.name: Chadulu H Group

texts.en:
Enitha has been a vegetable and charcoal seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for one year. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory to grow her business and pay school fees for her children.

Enitha is 40 years old and married with six children who are between the ages 7 and 27. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members Evodia, Lucy, Salma, and Verian. Each woman also has her own small business in Dodoma.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell in her business.

loans.name: Primary School In Makeni Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of a Primary School in Makeni. It was founded in 1974. Today, it has a total of 750 pupils with a staff of twenty-three teachers. Since its inception in 1974, the school has produced many of the professionals in town and the country at large.

This Primary School continues to prove itself in both the academic arena and in sport. Ninety-eight percent of the pupils they sent last academic year for the National Primary School Exams (NPSE) had clear passes. This academic year, they expect to have a 100% passes at the NPSE.

This is the first loan the school is seeking from SMT.  With this loan, they will be able to invest in some petty-trading in order to supplement their monthly salaries. Some however will use theirs to either buy pieces of furniture or in constructing houses. This loan will definitely improve the economic status of these teachers. 

John B. C. (left) is the head teacher of this school. Mr. C. was born in Kamalo village, about forty-seven miles from Makeni. He is fifty-five years of age, married with six children between the ages of two and thirty-four. John is currently building a second home for himself.  He will use his loan to buy building materials to continue with the building process. This house will consist of three bedrooms, a parlor, a store and a toilet. Once he is finished building it, it will be an estimated value of Le 10,000,000 – Le 11,000,000 (approx. US$ 3000 – US$ 3600).

loans.use: Buy building materials

loans.name: Yandaa

texts.en: Yandaa B. is a 70-year-old woman who lives with her daughter, daughter-in-law and granddaughter. She has been receiving her pension for the last 15 years; in addition, she runs her little business, as her pension is enough only to just scrape by and she doesn't want to ask her children for money. She rents a stall for clothing sales at the local market, specifically selling children's clothes for newborns. She has a total of four children. One of her children who lives with her helps her to buy clothes from a wholesale market. Yandaa's repeat clients are mostly mothers who just gave birth. (It is a Mongolian superstition not to buy anything for an unborn child). She is one of XacBank's repeat borrowers who has a very good credit history. She told XacBank's credit officer: "I don't want to be a trouble for my children; therefore, I'll keep my little business as long as I can."

loans.use: To buy clothes for newborns for her clothing sales

loans.name: Kann

texts.en: Kann T., 44, is married and resides with her husband in the Siem Reap province. Since 1999 she has been selling wood to earn a living. She is able to earn about US$2 per day. Her husband works as a farmer growing rice. He plants rice two times a year and makes US$10 per day. Mrs. Kann T. would like to take out a loan to purchase a grinding mill which she can rent to the local farmers and increase her profit.

loans.use: To purchase grinding mill.

loans.name: Lubajja Traders (C) Group

texts.en:
Huruna has been in the business of supplying coffee beans to factories in Mityana for about 10 years. He sells the beans from his 10-acre operation as well as coffee that he gathers from smaller operations. From his 10 acres, he is usually able to get two sacs of coffee per week.

Getting the coffee ready to sell is a time-consuming and laborious process. After picking the coffee pods, he lays them in the sun to dry. After they are dry, Huruna must crack open the individual pods and extract the coffee beans. Then he must pack these beans into large sacs and transport them to the factories to sell them.

Huruna has eight children ranging from 6 to 16 years old. They are all in school, so he and his wife have to search for ways to manage the large task of providing school fees for all of them. All of his children attend private schools. This is a sign that his business is making a difference in his family.

Huruna is requesting a loan of 2 million USH (UGX) to purchase sacs of coffee to resell. He says that if his business takes off, he would like to build some houses to rent to people in his community. His biggest dream is to travel around the world.

loans.use: To purchase sacs of coffee to resell

loans.name: Hatuyumbi Group

texts.en:
Mosi is a tailor and owns a small clothes shop in the Darajabovu neighborhood of Zanzibar. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $55. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for her shop. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home and pay school fees for her children.

Mosi is 27 years old, divorced, and has two children: aged 8 and 6.

Mosi will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Suma and Amina. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her shop

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi is 37 years old and married with no children. She sells shoes and clothes. She has been in this business for  the past four years. Ngozi hopes for a loan of  N50,000 to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny lives in the village of Barangay Natappian West Solana, Cagayan. Her husband works as a simple farmer. While free from farming duties, Jenny operates their old “kalesa” transport business that still exists in Solana, Cagayan. A “kalesa” is a cart which is pulled by a horse. Its use dates back to the Spanish regime in the Philippines. Jenny says that the “kalesa” is helpful to their daily living. It does not require the expense of gasoline, which is also a great contribution to the environment. She further said that this type of transportation will last for a long time and is something they can rely on.

She is asking for a loan of PHP 13,000 for business necessities such as improvement of the cart used in their transportation business. The cart they use is old and is in need of repair in order to give their passenger comfort as they ride. Jenny is 24 years old and soon will have a child to support with its education and basic needs.

loans.use: Business improvement

loans.name: Ever

texts.es:
El señor Ever M. G. vive en casa en alquiler, en la zona  de Llojeta, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor Ever es constructor, realizando trabajos en construcciones particulares con los que se mantiene.
Sus ingresos no son muy buenos y el pago de alquileres mensuales hace que no pueda ahorrar. 
El crédito solicitado es para la adquisición de un anticretico de una habitación, que le permitirá pagar menos que el alquiler mensualmente y que al cabo de un año tenga ahorrado el monto del anticretico.
Esta es la primera vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Ever M. G. lives in a rented home in the Llojeta zone on the east hillside of the city of La Paz. Ever is a construction worker and supports himself by working on particular construction jobs. He does not earn a lot and his monthly rent payments make it so that he cannot save. The loan that he is requesting it to acquire a room on anticredito (a system by which the tenant pays a fixed sum considered a loan to the property owner which they receive back in full when the rental period is over); this will allow him to pay less than the monthly rent and after a year he will have saved the anticredito amount. This is the first time that he has made a loan request and because he has favorably met the financial analysis criteria he has been approved for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The loan will be used to acquire a room on anticredito, which will allow him to not have to pay rent and to be able to save.

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es:
La señora Guillermina G. S. tiene 72 años, vive en el distrito del Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella no estudió, no tiene  hijos que dependen económicamente de ella.
Guillermina se dedica a la venta de abarrotes y cerveza en su bodega, cuando inicio con Manuela Ramos ya tenía su negocio, los productos los obtiene de un mercado del distrito y las bebidas son abastecidas directamente por la empresa que las elabora, su negocio lo desarrolla en su mismo domicilio.
El primer crédito que recibió fue de S/. 300 soles, el cual invirtió en la compra de productos como galletas, gaseosas y cervezas.
Este crédito de 800 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de cervezas y otros productos como galletas, gaseosas, arroz, azúcar.
Guillermina  tiene como sueño continuar con su bodega e implementar mas y trabajar conjuntamente con su esposo para  crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Guillermina G. S. is 72 years old and lives in the District of Porvenir in Trujillo Province, in the La Libertad region of Peru. She never went to school and doesn’t have any dependent children.
Guillermina sells groceries and beer from her general store. She had already set up her business when she started working with Manuela Ramos. She gets her products from the district market and obtains the drinks directly from the company that makes them. She runs her business in her home.
The first loan she received totalled 300 PEN and she used it to purchase products like biscuits, soft drinks, rice and sugar. She will use this 800 PEN loan to purchase beer and other products like biscuits, soft drinks, rice and sugar.
Guillermina dreams of maintaining her business, increasing her stock and working together with her husband to grow as a microentrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beer and other products like biscuits, soft drinks, rice and sugar

loans.name: Gissel Del Carmen

texts.es: Gissel del Carmen S. Martínez tiene 29 años de edad. Es madre soltera. Tiene 1 hijo a su cargo. Gissel tiene 6 años de dedicarse a este negocio. Su actividad económica es la venta de cosméticos. Ella es una joven muy activa y dinámica, le gusta mucho su trabajo gracias a una amiga que le enseñaron lo esencial con esta actividad, fue que ella se instruyó para mantener su negocio y salir adelante, todos los días por la mañana elle recorre los diferentes lugares que tiene que visitar para ofrecer sus productos. Por lo que tiene que estar por la tarde, ya que tiene que pasar por su hijo en la escuela. El destino del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de cremas, perfumes, desodorantes y pinturas de uñas. El sueño de ella ha sido establecer una tienda en la que ofrezca una variedad de productos.
texts.en:
Gissel del Carmen S. Martínez is 29 years old. She is a single mother. She has 1 child under her care. Gissel has dedicated herself to this business for 6 years. Her business is in the sale of cosmetics. She is a very active and dynamic young woman, and she enjoys her work very much. Thanks to a friend that taught her what was essential in this business, she was able to teach herself to manage this business and get ahead. Every day in the morning she travels to different places that she has scheduled to visit to sell her products. She has to be back in the afternoon, given that she has to pick up her son from school. The loan will be used as work capital to purchase creams, perfumes, deodorants, and nail polishes. Her dream has been to establish a store in which she can offer a variety of products.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital (to purchase creams, perfumes, deodorants, and nail polishes).

loans.name: El Guanacaste Group

texts.es:
El grupo Guanacaste está integrado por Roxana Judith P. Flores, Jaqueline Marveli L. y Eloisa M., ellas viven en la comarca Guanacastillo y pertenecen a la Iglesia Menomita la que les ayudado a poder construir sus humildes casas.

Este es el primer préstamo para este grupo conformado por mujeres emprendedoras, trabajadoras y capaces de salir adelante tan solo las detiene la falta de capital para poder invertir en sus negocios.

La coordinadora del grupo es la joven Roxana P. de 20 años de edad. Esta muchacha comenzó hace dos años  vendiendo ropa para adulto y niños en pequeñas cantidades pero actualmente tiene mayor demanda que no puede solventare por la falta de dinero para reinvertir. 

Las otras integrantes del grupo son  Jaqueline L. de 21 años de edad quien trabaja vendiendo ropa para adultos por pedidos  como  camisetas, pantalones, blusas y ropa interior a un precio favorable. Mientras Eloisa M. de 43 años de edad tiene una pulpería donde vende todo tipos de producto para la canasta básica de los pobladores.
texts.en:
The Guanacaste group consists of Roxana Judith P. Flores, Jaqueline Marveli L. and Eloisa M.. They live in the Guanacastillo region and belong to the Mennonite Church which has helped them build their humble homes. This is the first loan for this group of hard-working, entrepreneurial women who are capable of being successful but they are lacking the capital to be able to invest in their businesses. The coordinator of the group is 20 year old Roxana Picada. Two years ago she began selling adult and children’s clothing in small quantities but today she has high demand and she can’t meet it because she lacks money to reinvest in her business. The other members of the group are 21 year old Jaqueline L. who works selling adult clothing by order such as tshirts, pants, blouses, and underwear at a favorable price. 43 year old Eloisa M. has a convenience store where she sells all kinds of products to meet the basic needs of the community members.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a variety of shirts, blouses and pants

loans.name: Chaker

texts.en:
Chaker is a 44 year old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Chaker has been working as a carpenter for nine years. Chaker requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a new tool for his work. This is the first time that Chaker has requested a loan.
Chaker is special in his work because he does it well. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash. Chaker decided on doing his business because of his experience since he learned when he was young. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new tool for his work.

loans.name: Louise

texts.fr: Louise P. est une femme de 67ans, veuve et mère de 3 enfants. Elle fait de l’embauche porcine qu’elle aimerait développer. Son objectif est d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Louise P. is a 67 year old woman who is a widow and the mother of 3 children. She would like to develop her business fattening pigs. Her goal is to improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fattening pigs

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Seang R., 51, is married and lives with four of her children in the Phnom Penh. To earn a living, she has been selling food and beverages from home. She typically makes about US$15 per day, while her husband works in Ministry of land, making US$1.5 a day. One of the children is a construction worker and makes US$5 every day. Seang R. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to reinvest in her businesses. She will purchase more chairs and tables.

loans.use: To purchase more chairs and tables.

loans.name: Assiongbon

texts.fr: Ce monsieur a appris le métier de couture ; il a ouvert dans le quartier de Baguida à Lomé son atelier de couture. Depuis un certain temps, son atelier ne reçoit plus de clients comme par le passé ; c’est pour cette raison qu’il a acheté en 2006 une moto pour faire taxi ; il conduit lui-même son taxi-moto et confie la gestion de son atelier à un apprenti tailleur expérimenté. Grâce à cette nouvelle activité bien rentable pour lui, il a ouvert une petite cabine de téléphone cellulaire dans son atelier. Avec ces deux activités, il arrive à s’en sortir. Il voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des cartes de recharge pour sa cabine cellulaire ; le reste du prêt servira à réparer son taxi moto tombé en panne. Il est marié et a un enfant à sa charge.
texts.en:
This man learned the sewing trade. He opened his own sewing workshop in the neighborhood of Baguida in Lomé. For a while, his store has not received customers from foot-traffic. It is for this reason that in 2006 he purchased a motorcycle to use as a taxi. He drives the moto-taxi himself and has given the management of his workshop over to an experienced tailor's apprentice. Thanks to the profitability of this new business, he opened a small cellular telephone booth in his workshop. With these two businesses, he is able to properly handle his finances. He would like a credit from the micro-finance group WAGES to purchase cell-phone credit re-fill cards; he will use the remainder of the loan for repairs of his moto-taxi. He is married and has on child in his care.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase phone credit refill cards and to repair his moto-taxi.

loans.name: Saidat

texts.en:
Saidat is a 27 year old woman who is married with three children. She resides and owns a four room house where she is staying with four people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but, unfortunately, no running water.  

Saidat owns a stall selling second hand clothing. She works in Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala. On average she receives 10 customers a day. She has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for seven years; she is currently on her fourteenth loan, working with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication. Her challenges include defaulters and the rainy season because when it rains very few customers come to her stall since it is in a muddy place. Saidat wants to use this loan to buy more second hand clothes. She aspires to expand her business and eventually sell only wholesale.

loans.use: purchasing more second hand clothes

loans.name: Fatima Ii Group

texts.es: El grupo “Fátima II” esta representado por la señora  Elsa y conformado por 15 miembros los cuales realizan diferentes actividades para el sustento D. sus familias como la venta D. artículos D. la canasta familiar en pequeñas pulperías, venta  D. comida al paso, refrigerios,  servicio  D. moto taxi, venta D. cosméticos  y el servicio mecánico. Dentro del ámbito comercial y D. servicios el nivel competitivo es alto en especial para los socios que tienen poca mercadería  y no pueden competir con las grandes tiendas  que pueden abaratar sus costos y seguir en la competencia, pero las socias tienen mucha experiencia y ganas D. trabajar con el incentivo D. sacar adelante a sus familias que es el impulso para salir adelante. El destino del préstamo es para incrementar su mercadería así como la compra D. insumos y materiales que ayuden a obtener un mejor capital D. trabajo para hacer frente a la competencia. En cuanto a la experiencia las socias van cursando su primer ciclo por lo que no tienen mucha experiencia en grupos solidarios pero tienen muchos deseos D. crecer y este deseo les impulsa a seguir adelante para brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad D. vida.
texts.en:
The “Fátima II” Group is represented by Elsa and is comprised of 15 members who support their families in different ways such as selling basic foods at small local stores, selling street food, selling snacks, moto-taxi [motorcycle with attached cab for passengers] service, cosmetics sales, and mechanic service. In the world of commerce and services there is a high level of competition, especially for those who don't have much merchandise and can't compete with the large stores that can reduce their costs and stay competitive. But the members of the “Fátima II” Group have a great desire to work, with the incentive of providing for their families which is their motive for trying to get ahead. This loan is to be used to increase their merchandise supply as well as to buy food and materials that will help them get better working capital in order to take on the competition. As far as experience, the members are going through their first cycle, so don't have much experience in community banks, but they have many hopes of growing and this is what drives them to keep going forward to proviD. their families with the best quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Shimmin, KI. Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Abiola

texts.en:
Abiola is 40 years old and married with two children. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. Abiola sells foodstuffs and also has a grinding machine. With the profits from these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the needs of her family. She has been in business for a long time.
Abiola has been with Kiva partner LAPO for two years. She is now requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita S. is from the town of Gamu. She is 58 years old. Pacita is married and has 12 adult children. To make a living, Pacita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting vegetables for sale. Pacita has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Pacita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pacita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and young crops to raise. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and young crops to raise

loans.name: Mary Joy's Group

texts.en:
Mary Joy A. is from the village of Brgy. Tuao North, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 23 years old. Mary Joy is the group leader for a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or default.

Mary Joy is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Mary Joy owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling pork and chicken barbeque. Mary Joy has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.


In 2008, Mary Joy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Joy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Mary Joy is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand the range of products offered. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Mary Joy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. 


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the range of products offered

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mr. Sophal T., 36, is a horse cart driver, and has been married to Mrs. Bunna Nao, 30, since 1994. They are living on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. His wife sells fish in the local market. 

The house where they stay is old and breaks down. It’s difficult for them to live there. Sophal is asking for his first loan of $600 to add to his own money to build a new house.

loans.use: To add to his own money to build new house.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita M., is already 64 years old but still works on her farm to earn an income. She grows rice. Her husband also tills the farm. Both of them are happy working together because the income they make in their rice farm will pay for the needs of their children, though most of them are already married.

Rosita would like to ask for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: H.g.

texts.en:
M. is a 24-year-old woman living with her husband along with their only child. Her husband has a small masonry goods supply business and M. helps him in his work.

They want to expand their business as their family size is getting bigger now. They need money for their child’s education and other basic needs of daily life.

loans.use: To buy stone, bricks, sand and cement for her husband's business

loans.name: Enecita

texts.en:
Enecita B. is from the village of P-10, Puerta, Lurugan, Valencia City. She is 51 years old, separated from her spouse, and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Enecita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Enecita has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Enecita joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Enecita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her third from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

location.town: P-10, Puerta, Lurugan, Valencia City, Bukidnon

loans.name: Blanca Mayra

texts.es:
Blanca Mayra Ramírez R.  tiene 31 años, es casada, y  tiene cuatro hijos.  Vive en el cantón de Guaranda en la provincia de Bolívar.

El socio es  miembro de la ventanilla rural Grupo Enmanuel es un recinto que se encuentra a cuarenta y cinco minutos del Cantón Guaranda capital de la Provincia de Bolívar.  Son 17 socios en total, es una comunidad Agrícola y Ganadera son indígenas hablan Quechua en su totalidad 
Blanca trabaja en la agricultura para incrementar la economía de la familia.  Los cultivos que más sobresalen son el maíz, cebada, trigo y papas  además se dedica a la cría animales en la casa como chanchos, cuyes y borregos  los productos vende en la casa y lo que siembra vende en el mercado mayorista de Guaranda cada seis meses.

La cultura principal es el carnaval que se celebra todos los años en febrero.  También, a Blanca  le gusta lavar cocinar y coser en los tiempos libres. 

El socio solicita el crédito para comprar insumos para el trabajo del campo y sobre todo para fertilizantes y abonos.  Su meta es tener una buena actividad económica para la familia.  Los desafíos que enfrenta son los problemas climáticos y las enfermedades que afectan a los cultivos.
texts.en:
Blanca Mayra Ramírez R. is 31 years old, married, and has four kids. She lives in the Guaranda cantón [a territorial unit or subdivision, below a province] in the province of Bolívar. She is a member of the solidarity group Group Enmanuel. It is an enclosure that is 45 minutes from Guaranda cantón, the capital of Bolívar. There are 17 group members total. Guaranda is an agricultural and livestock community where the indigenous speak Quechua. Blanca works in agriculture in order to boost the economy of the family. Her crops that stand out are corn, barley, wheat, and potatoes. In addition, she raises animals at home, like pigs, goats, and sheep. She sells her products at home and what is left over is sold in the major market of Guaranda every six months. The main cultural event is carnaval, which is celebrated ever year in February. Blanca also likes to do laundry, cook, and sew in her free time. This solidarity group member asks for a loan to purchase inputs for her field work, and above all for fertilizer and manure. Her goal is to have good economic activity for the family. The challenges that she faces are climate problems and diseases that affect the crops.

Translated from Spanish by Flavia Garcia, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inputs for agricultural work

loans.name: Julian

texts.es:
Julián tiene 32 años, es casado y tiene 4 hijos. Vive en la localidad de “Quimbiri”, ubicada en la ceja de la selva peruana, donde tienen su casa propia.

Anteriormente era únicamente agricultor, pero en el presente se dedica al sector transporte, específicamente al transporte de pasajeros en su motocarro. Su recorrido empieza a las 6 AM y termina a las 10 PM. Este trabajo le gusta mucho, pues le brinda la oportunidad de socializar con sus clientes y  además obtiene buenas ganancias. 
Para el futuro, piensa reincorporarse a la actividad  agrícola, sin dejar de lado su trabajo actual, para que así tenga ingresos paralelos.

Este es su quinto préstamo con MFP, donde se compromete a cumplir con sus respectivos pagos mensuales; además hace hincapié en la buena organización que existe en su banco comunal, por lo que se siente satisfecho de ser parte.

Con el dinero solicitado comprará terrenos de cultivo para café, también hará el mantenimiento de su motocarro, con el propósito de trabajar con  mayor seguridad y confianza para sus clientes.
texts.en:
Julián is 32 years old, and is married with four children. He lives in Quimbiri, in the Peruvian jungle, where he has his own house. Previously, Julián was working in agriculture, but now he works in the transportation sector, transporting passengers in his mototaxi. His workday begins at 6AM and ends at 10 PM. He enjoys this work, as he has the opportunity to chat with his clients and also earn good money. In the future, Julián would like to renew his agricultural work without giving up the mototaxi. In this way, he would have two parallel income streams. This is Julián’s fifth loan with MFP, where he commits to making his monthly payments. Also, he makes an effort to help with the good organization of his communal bank, and he is happy to be a part of it. With this loan, Julián will buy land for the cultivation of coffee. He will also spend some money on maintenance of his mototaxi, so as to provide more security and confidence for his customers.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy land for agriculture and do vehicle mainenance

loans.name: Hawanatu

texts.en: Hawanatu W. has been a client of LAPO Sierra Leone for almost two years now, and she has taken three previous loans. She used the previous loans to expand her shop. Hawanatu is forty-five years old and married with eight children; she has four sons and four daughters. Her eldest child is in college, two are in secondary school, and the younger five are in primary school. Hawanatu's husband is a building contractor, and they live in Laka where she has a building-material shop. Hawanatu is asking for a loan of 3,000,0000 SLL to enable her buy more of items for sale.

loans.use: This loan will be used to purchase building materials for sale.

loans.name: Ronald

texts.es: Ronald tiene 31 años, vive con sus padres en casa de un familiar. Hace más de 8 años se dedica en la venta de productos básicos para el consumo humano, para ello se asoció con un familiar en el invirtieron para alquilar un local comercial, ubicada en una calle muy céntrica de su ciudad. Desde entonces vende al por mayor y menor gran variedad de productos de primera necesidad, además se organizan para atender su clientela. Paralelo a esta actividad, durante los fines de semana se dedican a vender animales y también a la agricultura, éste último le ayuda para su consumo propio, en donde siembra maíz y papa. Su negocio en la venta de productos le ha sido muy rentable, por lo que desea mas adelante ampliar su negocio y emprender uno nuevo e independiente.  Este es su séptimo crédito con MFP, por tanto se compromete a ser muy responsable con sus pagos. El crédito que solicita, invertirá para abastecerse de más productos y además en la compra de abono para su siguiente siembra de papa.
texts.en:
Ron is 31 years old and lives with his parents in the family home. Eight months ago he began selling basic consumer products. For him, he associated with a partnership to invest in renting a local business located on a very central street in the city. Since then, he sells a wide variety of wholesale and retail products that include basic necessities. In addition, he organizes them according to his client's needs. Parallel to this activity, on the weekends he sells animals and agricultural products; the later helps his own efforts in planting corn and potatoes. His business selling products has been very favorable, for his desire to move his business forward, and to become a new independent business owner. This is his seventh loan with MFP, and he promises to be very responsible with his payments. With the loan he's requesting, he will invest in building a supply of more products and even more so, buy fertilizer for his subsequent potato plantings.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build up a supply of products for his business

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es:
La Sra. Silvia, vive en casa propia en la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí, tiene 47 años de edad y se encuentra casada con don Victor  con el que tiene 3 hijos que se encuentran estudiando en la universidad; ambos trabajan juntos en la confección de chamarras.
